text: Dark brown pour. Toffee and raisin aroma. Dark fruit and booze taste. Hints of oak in there as well. Really good
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2017 Purchased at LCBO in 750ml bottle for about $10. Nice beer. Fantastic for the Belgian style of beer. Can easily not notice its as strong as 10% ABV.
Bottled at Clubhouse BFD event. Pours dark, tan head. Aroma is Belgian spice, esters, cinnamon, nutmeg, raisin, fig, plum, sweet. Flavor is raisin, plum, fig. Sweet dark fruit. Very sweet.
Dark brown pour, finger of tan head. Nose is dark malt and spice. Bittersweet. Middle is coco, currants, nutmeg, charged malt. Finish is warm and bittersweet.

750ml bottle from LCBO. 10% alc/vol. Pours an opaque deep brown colour with two fingers of lasting head. Aromas of toffee, raisins, prunes and a whiff of cinnamon. Taste matches the aroma with notes of oak and has a well balanced hoppy finish. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Excellent Belgian strong ale. It reminds me of belgian quads.
2016. Smells malty, bready, a bit of caramel. Has some maple taste, some sweetness, slight alcohol character, very full body, good beer!

2011 vintage, a few days prior to 5 yr best before window, pours a dark brow n with 1 finger creamy tan head, slight carbonation but mostly clings to side, nose is so reminiscent of a recent fig ginger spread recently tried,getting some wood presence from the oak, mouthfeel is oh so smooth, unbelievably soft, easy to drink, but has dark fruit, sour plum n raisin, alcohol is smooth as can be, could pass for a mashup btwn a Barleywine and Belgian dubbel, quite impressed how this tastes after 5 years, very nice all around..

Sweet fig, plum, and raisin aromas and flavors. Dark brownish-purple color with a creamy white head of foam. Oak influences come into play on the finish with a bit of a barleywine character. Hides the 10% easily.

BB backlog, Bottle, Pours reddish brown with a medium off white head. Smell and flavor of prunes, orange, belgian yeast, oak, and light licorice. Medium to fuller mouthfeel with tons of warming quality in the chest. I liked this one more than other Unibroue anniversaries.

2015 Vintage (Cellared 1 year). Smells very sugary and fruity. Pours a dark gold brown (much darker then I was expecting with this style). Head lasts to the last drop. Taste is like it smells, fruity and sweet. You can tell it has an elevated alcohol content, but not what was advertised. Very sweet on the tongue. Sweet aftertaste. Some booziness. Overall I was very happy. I buy year after year. I will let you know how it tastes in 10 years. MB The Beer Bear-on

Bouteille datée du 08/12/2014, bue après un peu plus de 22 mois. Robe acajou claire surmontée dun col de mousse blanchâtre et assez laiteux. Mince dentelle collante. Arômes de pommes, levures belges et fraises (peut-être un début de madérisation). Il y a également de la vanille, jus de mûres, herbes fraîches, bois gorgé de liqueur sucrée, caramel. Arrière-plan de miel léger, figues et poire. En bouche, confits de baies, figues et raisins bleus. Toujours ces saveurs de pomme et autres fruits du verger. Suivent ensuite de la vanille, alcool sucré, bois. Une forte enveloppe maltée et bourrée de levures belges rapellant les brunes trappistes accompagne le tout. La finale laisse dégager de légères épices typiques des bières dUnibroue qui sont franchement bien intégrées aux saveurs. Le haut taux dalcool ne paraît aucunement. Je trouve la texture en bouche superbe. Cest à la fois lisse et soyeux. Et accompagnée dun corps rond et équilibré, cest une bière qui se boit trop bien.

Im not a big fan of the style, but when this 2013 bottle showed up on the local liquor store clearance shelf for $3.99 (what are they thinking?), I had to try it. Highly carbonated, the cork popped of with barely a nudge. The heavy carbonation gives it a lighter palate than I was expecting. Lots of dark fruit, spice, the oak comes through near the end. ABV is completely non-apparent, though there it is invoking some face-warming. Im enjoying it.

750 ml bottle dated December 2010. The aroma is clove, raisin. Pours a ruby brown with big light brown head, fully diminishing. The taste is sweet/sour then bitter. The body is medium, the texture thin, the carbonation a little fizzy and the finish long. Ive had this before and loved it, maybe aged too long.

From a corked bottle into a 2016 New Belgium stem glass. Pours brown with significant head and lace. Aroma of anise cookies, dark malt, orange zest. Significant carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of rich malts, watermelon rind, vanilla, minerals, oak, licorice, kumquat zest, funky yeast esters. Overall big, complex, unique, tasty yet challenging.

appearance: dark clear maroon, short creamy light tan head.  aroma: complex, with treacle, raisin, candi sugar, burnt caramel, cherries in dark syrup, some chocolate, a hint of port wine.  taste: 	sweet and boozy; theres a ton here--candi sugar, caramel, chocolate, stone fruit, cherry pipe tobacco, leather, a hint of coffee, vanilla, and bourbon.  finish: slightly numbing, with a pleasant and slowly building alcohol warmth; lingering sweetness and some phenolic yeasty notes. notes: What a beer. Huge and complex, alcohol well-hidden for 10%, lots of complimentary flavors, some of which are not common to the style. 2011 vintage, aged 5 years, shared with Zoltan.

December 2010 bottling rated May 2016. Malty alcoholic nose, hints of citrus and smoke and phenolic sourness. Medium sweet taste with a backbone of bitterness and a hint of sourness. Medium bodied, pleasant sour-birther aftertaste. Wonderful strong ale, The faint smokiness and sourness makes it different from many of the other figgy-raisin strong ales.

Bottle share. Pours a hazy brown color with a sudsy off-white head. Aroma of oak, dark fruit, vanilla, toffee. Flavor followed the nose pretty perfectly. Full bodied, creamy texture, softly carbed, and a warming finish.

Big bottle from Haskells with commonmac as last beer of the opening weekend of March madness. 2014 bottle. Hazy plum with silky foamy pretty head. Belgian yeast and slightly tart nose. Very little alcohol aroma, maybe some raisin. Yeast funk, dark fruit, maybe a little light chocolate , sugar . A Belgian tasting strong ale. perfect mouthfeel with a tiny bit of bite and burn. Finish is comfortable and slightly warming. This is amazing. Makes me feel good.

750 ml bottle acquired at a Haskells in Mpls. 2014 edition according to the bottle. Consumed to celebrate the finale of the first weekend of March Madness with commonshawn. Moeder Lambic glasses serving as consumption vessels. Attractive copper/amber color with a silky off white head that is consistently present during consumption. Aroma features plum, raisin, brown sugar, and maybe a little caramel. Taste is very complex. Dark fruits - raisin and plum definitely come through. A strong rush of sugary malts as the sip progresses. Alcohol presence felt bringing with it a bourbon-like mouthfeel and warmth. The finish is very unique...almost a toasted marshmallow quality and a tingling mouthfeel that lingers during the aftertaste. Saved this bottle for almost 6 months after purchase and well worth the wait. Ill begin my search for another bottle as soon as I push "Add My Rating".

Its a muddy, murky brown pour with an off white, foamy head reminiscent of the one that Rochefort 10 produces. Aromas are complex with everything from raisins to mint entering the mix. On the tongue, there are figs, dates, raisins,and a smidgen of booziness. Some vanilla on the swallow too.
Overall, this is a very complex beer, best sipped (and not just because of the high ABV) to get the full enjoyment out of, especially considering how it morphs and evolves as ambient room temperature effects it. This is a truly outstanding brew out of Canada and one very well worth your effort to track down.

Bottle/Fest.

A- Stone fruit, honey, complex.

A- Brown color, cloudy liquid, off white head.

T- BBQ sauce, fruity.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, complex finish.

O- This had a ton of flavors going on and they balanced so well I struggled to tell them apart, but boy did they blend well. I got a weird bbq sauce taste that was actually quite welcoming.
2011 vintage. Copper pour, fairly large head. Fruit up front in aroma and taste, raisin, plus, prune, dates, oak, brown sugar. Fairly high carbonation.

2016/02/11 - Pours a hazy brown-amber colour with a frothy, khaki head that lingers and moderate lacing. Aroma is dried dark fruit (raisin, figs, plumbs,etc...), oaky vanilla, toffee, honey, doughy yeast and light tobacco. Taste is more oak and vanilla, honey, yeasty dough, dried figs/raisins an light booze. Mouthfeel medium and silky with smooth carbonation and spicy, drying, mildly warming finish. Really nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thick cloudy copper color with a pink hue and powerful carbonation activity. Extra foamy, delicate, beige 3 finger sparkly head, creating a foam island and lasting around 12 minutes, with some strong legs.

Aromas and flavors of dark fruits, citrus, caramel, honey or maple, floral and herbal spices. Well intensified, delicious rich super fruity taste, slightly vinous but in a soft sweet way, with hints of orange/lemony/coriander/apple slightly bitter feel and a pleasant earthy oak sensation.

Slick, almost creamy, full body with some perfect carbonation. Balanced finish ending with a slightly bitter and dry, thick dark berries mouth coat and perfectly spiced aftertaste.

Overall : The perfect craft; sexy lovely look, warming, awesome freshness, complex delicious flavors, inviting smell, accessible...what else do you want?

Cloudy chestnut colored pour with a substantial khaki head. Aroma is fig, coffee, vanilla, plum, a bit of booze, and dark cherries. Tastes of dried dark cherries, prunes, mild chocolate, figs, and a little bit of alcohol.  Tobacco and oak add depth. Medium body with fair carbonation. Quite earthy with a slight bitterness to balance out the dark malts. The aroma is even superior to the taste.
Deep walnut pour with a large frothy tan head and lace. Fruity, tangy malt aroma. Nice spice malt flavour. Peppery finish. Tasty brew.

Poured from a 2011 750ml bottle in January 2016. 

Murky, rusty brown with a khaki head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of dark fruit, chestnuts, toffee and oak. 

Taste of toffee, dark fruit, spices, yeast, oak and molasses. 

Medium body medium/high carbonization with a creamy mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to my cousin Jeff for bringing to my place for patriots playoff game. Amber pour nose of dark fruit and oak. Tastes of oak, plums, fig, raisins, tobacco, s e spice, yeast, and booze. Fine medium body light warming. Chocolate finish.

Bottle No. 2012-17205. Copper color. Aromas of chestnuts, toffee, and black raspberry tart with a slightly chewy, tangy, effervescent, fruity medium-to-full body and a silky, complex, long chocolate tangerine peels and oak finish. A superbly balanced and flavorful oak-aged ale. It has a best before date of 12-18-2017, but I just couldnt wait.

Bottle at Eulogy. 2011 vintage in 2016. Murky brown pour. Quickly dissipating off-white head. Smooth medium semi-sweet caramel bready malts. Black walnuts. Raisins. Figs. Dates. Dark bready. Warms to some nail polish remover. Not silky or creamy but very smooth. Wish it was darker.
Très bonne bière en apéro. Un peu fumée elle est très bien équilibrée. Laisse un bon goût en bouche.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android
Bottle as Xmas present. Poured dark amber brown with beige head. Aroma sweet caramel smoke. Light carb med bod. Taste malty sweet oak.

Murky brown unfiltered body with an effluent off white head of large foam bubbles about 3.5 cm thick that lasts for the entire glass. Aromas of wet banana bread dough, some spiciness at first and an aged oak wood tinge in the end. A complex flavour of gingerbread, some yeast and deep demerara sugar. Bold malt and bold bitter profile. Mouthfeel is oily and lingering but the whole experience is remarkably balanced and in the end smooth and satisfying.
Bottled. The aroma is chocolate, red wine and sugar. The taste is very smooth liquor like and the finish long.

2013 vintage. Too complex for me? Im a simple guy! This is another beautiful pour from these masters of beer appearance - dark garnet with half-finger of lasting, clingy tiny mocha bubbles. Aroma has wood, spice, and slight vinous notes. After the first sip, the wine aroma becomes dominant, I suppose due to some olfactory action. The flavor is immediately winy with tangy dark fruit lingering amongst the notable wood. I like wine and I like beer, but Im not sure this is what Im looking for.

750ml bottle, original 2007 batch.
Pours a medium copper, greenish tinge, off-white head.
Complex, matured aroma, caramel, wood, cherries (?), phenols, coffee, chestnut.
Dry, medium body and bitterness, balanced CO2.
Mature, complex taste, wine-like notes, dried fruit, caramel, coffee, cherries, wood, tobacco.
Very well balanced. (2015-12-18)

Poured from 2013 bottle. Hazy brown with large tan head, sticks around for a while. Smooth taste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours beautiful, hazy chestnut brown with red highlights, large tan head that persists and leaves significant skim and lacing for hours, if you let it.
Big nose of molasses, oak, rum, banana, spice, dark fruit. On the palate, cherries, raisins and prunes step up to replace the banana, and the spice note resolves into cinnamon, allspice, white pepper. Maple syrup jousts with a bit of bitter heat, as is added to a young port.
Its a wonderfully complex, evolving brew. The 2013 bottle Im drinking at the moment started out almost too big, but moderated with aeration. The alcohol remains subordinate to the flavors, but Im glad Im not driving anywhere later.

2013 bottle poured into snifter. Pours a hazy ruby brown with a thick, lively light khaki head. Lacing is soapy and very sticky, shimmering and almost crystalline. The aroma is yeast, malt, dark fruit, rum and lots of oak. The flavor is complex and balanced - Belgian yeast, dark fruit, molasses, booze, oak, and a gentle bitterness that rides a long finish with a hint of spice. Medium body and well carbonated. The 10% ABV is present but not overpowering, and may have mellowed the profile during aging. Great Belgian.

2015 750 ml bottle. Pours a clear ruby caramel with a lively off white head that sticks to the glass. Aroma has notes of Belgian yeast, dark candy sugar, dark fruits, and woody notes. Taste is balanced. Dark caramel, dark fruits, candy sugar, yeast, spice, and a touch of wood notes. Medium body with a high carbonation. Slightly syrupy in the mouth with an effervescent carbonation. Overall a very nice Belgian beer. Lots of dark fruits, dark sugar, yeast, and spice.

2011 bottle domed in the dining room
Pours a deep reddish brown color with a big, tight, tan head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.

The aroma is rich & reasonably fruit forward defiantly has some pear & dried cherry maybe a little prune. Its a touch nutty and certainly pretty woody, & lightly roasty. 

Well this is a complex beast of a beer, theres no doubt that there is oak in there, maybe a little more than Id normally like but with everything else going on it works about as well as it could. Its nutty, lightly bitter, and quite fruit forward with plenty of pear, plum, and dark cherry. The alcohol is on all accounts a part of the flavor, it drinks like a 10%er but thats not to say this element is unpleasant at all, it gives it a sort of "warming" character that works well with the fruit, wood, etc. As it warms some chocolate, roast, & dark brown sugar come forward a bit. It seems like its spiced, and it seems a reasonable proposition that it might... its got some bitter orange peel if I were to guess, but beyond that Im having a hard time putting my finger on anything specifically. 

The palate is heavy, but the texture is velvety. 
Fantastic beer on all accounts, & despite being 4 years old no real negative affects of aging seem to have taken hold here.

Bottle. Earthy leather aroma. Pours a very dark reddish brown with off white head and some nice lacing. Taste is light to medium sweet. Full bodied, with with a thick texture. A wonderful Belgian style beer.

Huge fan head, good retention and lacing. Murky brownish ruby colour. Banana, raisins, plum in the aroma. Matching flavours but the banana fades a little and lets the other flavours come forward as it warms. Spicy, molasses, dark fruit. Very complex. Maybe a little too much residual sweetness left over from the candy syrup, leaves a little too much of the syrup flavour/mouthfeel behind. Med-full mouthfeel with med-high carbonation. Lingering sweetness.

Bottle. It poured a hazy amber color with a beige head. The aroma was of malts, yeast and some sourness. The taste was similar to the aroma with dark fruits, raisin, molasses, oak and some peppery spices. Very nice.

Poured from a cork and cage 750 mL bottle into Belgian snifter. This 2011 bottle has a best by date of 12-12-2016.

Pours with a dark, hazy, reddish brown body covered by a modest size light tan head that has little retention and leaves minimal lacing.

Aroma: Alcohol esters, mixed dark dried fruits including raisins, cinnamon(!), clove, and fruitcake.

Flavor: Rich and complex with light cinnamon and clove, faint yeast, mixed dark dried fruits and hints of brandy, molasses, and fruitcake. Bitter-sweet. 

Feel: Medium-full body. Nicely smooth, Alcohol warming for sure, but it avoids the bite youd expect from a 10% brew. 

Overall: This is a unique, appropriately complex Belgian Strong Dark Ale. Its drinkable for a 10% ale. Worth seeking out. It was allowed to warm for about 30 minutes but still improved with further warming.

(bottle) murky brown colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of coconut and dark berries, slightly oxidized, with big notes of liquorice, dark bread crusts and caramel. flavour is mostly caramel and bubble gum, with more coconut, alcohol, some milk chocolate and pears in the finish. heavy-bodied with lively carbonation.

04/12/2007, with jfb and jonas. Hazy brown color with small tan head. sweet caramel aroma, some fruits, plum, maybe cherries, booze, oxidized. Taste is more caramel, milk chocolate, plum, booze, some dusty notes. Low carbonation. Still very good.
Lots of plums, dark fruit, aniseed and tons of carbonation. Good stuff but too carbonated

Bottle, 09/28/2015, 2012 bottle, thanks to Scott. Pours a deep mahogany color, thin off-white fizzy head. Aroma is fruity sweet caramel, plum, nutty earth notes, cloves, light banana. Taste is chewy caramel, nutty, banana bread, figs, Belgian yeast. Medium thick body, carbonation not too aggressive. Well done, tasty.
2014 bottle; 750ml->Trappist. Deep copper-brown with moderate beige head. Dark fruit, candy, Belgian yeast, malt. Very Quad-like, very sweet. Good.
Bottle from2011. Pours a dark red, brown color. Aroma is yeasty, some sugary dark fruits. Taste is sweet, plums or cherry, not the yeasty Belgium character. Nice beer.
opened as a joke and was delicious! Nutty, high carb and dry. Molasses and caramel flavors withoout the sugar. Which is very impressive. Nice!
Surprisingly solid beer. Brown color with light tan head. Aroma is nutty, malty, light toffee. Taste is dry and malty. Way easy to drink for the abv, good stuff.

Well... slew the bottle before i had a chance to rate it.

Overall a pretty average beer. Smooth but not a strong aroma and not a lot of flavor. Sugary lighter. Some dates and such. Certainly not a bad beer but nothing amazing.
Bottle pour split, thanks Andrew. This was the 2013 version, very nice amber pour, sweet aroma I get kind of black licorice in the aroma. Deep flavor, spices, little bitter. Very nice beer.

750 mL bottle, poured and split. Cork exploded off this one. 2013 vintage. Pours a swirling caramel brown color with a cola fizz head. Wood like, raisin spice aroma. Very nice flavor with some vanilla, plum fruit, and maybe some cinnamon spice. Has a bitter hop finish very late. High carb here. Very tasty strong ale. Probably my favorite beer from these guys.

Chocolate brown pour and brown lace not much head. Aroma is caramel malt, booze and toasted hops. Flavor is dank and dark with burnt toasted complexion and savory sweet malt with bits of citrus. Well done strong ale.

750 ml bottle. Pours a rusty brown/red with a huge off-white head, plenty of carbonation. Aromas of wood, leather, plum, and raisin. Tastes of plum, raisin, and alcohol. Full bodied, medium carbonation, long alcohol finish. Overall, big bold tastes that remind me of Westvletern XII.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2016 Une belle surprise que cette bouteille de 2013 qui est apparue sur les tablettes dun de mes détaillants préférés... Les levures sont typiquement très présentes, supportées par la banane, lalcool et un côté boisé moins dominant quà mon souvenir. Des notes de porto sont perceptibles en arrière-goût, de même que du tabac (une première dans une bière pour moi). Vraiment très bonne!!!

Pour la version 2014, cest moins dans mes cordes... Je ne sais pas si le fait quelle ait été incluse dans une promotion vraiment avantageuse récemment était lié à son état de madérisation avancé. Le nez est composé de prunes, dates et porto mais cest clairement oxydé. Il men reste 7 bouteilles ;-( Cest moins sucré que la 2013, et plus amer. En bouche, on détecte facilement un goût de brûlé plutôt déplaisant et décevant pour un produit de ce calibre. Peut-être le cas dune seule bouteille, on verra... 7/5/7/3/14=3.6/5.0

Poured a nice foamy brownish head with a deep brown appearance. Aroma is of darker malts, spices. The flavour is pretty mixed and varied. Very spicy feeling on the palate, roasts, caramel, yeast, darker type fruits all come together in the overall taste. Mouthfeel is extremely tingly with a tinge of alcohol aftertaste. Hard to believe this is 10%abv. Nicely hidden. Under the impression this is a yearly ritual. If so, bring on 2013 and beyond...

750 mL bottle. Fairly deep hazy chestnut brown pour. Tall foamy tan head. Lots of lacing and great retention. Aroma of toasted malt, toffee, cloves, banana, yeast. Taste is medium sweet, along same lines as aroma with a fairly spicy finish. Hints of warming alcohol throughout. Medium to full body with lively carbonation. Excellent.

Poured from a bottle. Market brown color, medium white color. Sweet malt and pepper aroma. Full body with a sweet malt flavor and medium finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice ruby reddish brown color. A very nice aroma of dark fruit and a little from French oak barrels. Taste is mostly the same as the nose, with a nice dry malty finish. A really really solid Belgian beer!

Cloudy sewage color with 1.5-inches of caramel head, moderately fine. Aroma is grass, some raisin, light caramel and dates, dry scone, a touch of candy. Body is watery and slightly syrupy, medium weight, medium coarseness carbonation with moderate burn. Flavor is green herbal grass with minerals and hay, slightly astringent, hint of molasses a bit of pear juice. Overall: I feel like I may have kicked up some sediment in transporting this (unfortunately); nonetheless, the beer could be great but has mineral/astringent notes that make it taste slightly off, and the cloudiness is unattractive. I wish it were more to me.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours deep golden amber, nose is caramel, chocolate, pine, yeasty, taste is similar.

750 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a
dark hazy copperish brown with a couple fingers of tan head. Retention is good and a lot of lacing is left behind. 
Aroma:
Cloves, malt, toasted caramel, cereal.
Flavours:
Burnt caramel, cloves, cereal, grain, moca, prunes, bit of molasses.
Mouthfeel:
Smooth and on the thinner side.
Overall: This is so smooth that youd have no idea it is 10% abv just by tasting it. Great combination of burnt caramel, cereal/grain and many other flavours. Despite so much going on, everything is in perfect balance. A really great beer overall.

ENG: 750ml bottle from Liquor Mart, Winnipeg. Dated 2014, No. 2013-38240. Poured into the tulip, gives very hazy / opalescent dark brown color, like a earl grey tea but mixed with honey or something hazy. Thick, creamy tan head and some lacing. In aromas there are cloves, bananas, champagne, caramel and notes of herbal hops. Tastes sweet champagne with banana flavor, a bit smoky, caramel and malty. Heavy sour then woody to bitter aftertaste. A lot of booze feeling, high carbonation, medium to high body. Wheat beers are not in my style very much, so I might give wrong opinion on this one, but I think its a bit too soury, although overall the palate is quite complex and interesting.
PL: Butelka 750ml kupiona w Liquor Mart Winnipeg. Datowana 2014, nr partii 2013-38240. Przelana do kieliszka, daje dość mocno mętną / opalizującą, ciemno-brązową barwę, trochę jak earl grey zmieszany z miodem, lub innym, gęstym dodatkiem. Piana gęsta, kremowa i nieco lejsingu. W aromatach zdecydowanie goździki, banany, szampan, karmel i nuty ziołowych chmieli. W smaku słodki szampan z posmakami banana, nieco wędzone, karmel i słody. Mocny kwaśnawy, potem drzewny, gorzki posmak. Dużo boozeu, wysokie nasycenie, średnie do wysokiego odczucie w ustach. Piwa pszeniczne to nie do końca moja bajka, także moja opinia może być niezbyt miarodajna, ale osobiście uważam, że kwaśność w tym piwie jest zbyt duża. Jednak podsumowując, paleta smaków jest tu dość rozbudowana i interesująca.

Pours clear deep amber with one finger of frothy light beige head diminishing gradually to a thin skim, moderate lacing. (4/5) Nose is caramel malt, Belgian yeast banana and cloves, dark fruits, oak and leather, tobacco. (8/10) Taste is moderate sweet, mild bitter. (9/10) Medium body, lively carbonation, lingering spicy finish with a moderate alcohol warming. (5/5)

I sound like a broken record when talking about Unibroue, but they really do a very impressive job of the Belgian styles. This thing is complex and has benefited from nearly a year in my cellar (and nearly two in the bottle), mellowing the ABV and tempering the woody and vinous notes. Lots of dark rich fruit, and an almost nutty finish. I could have thrown a lot more aroma comparisons in there: bubblegum, cinnamon, citrus peel, raisins, bread dough - basically, if you can think it, you can find it in there, especially as it warms and opens up. Yet, for all the complexity of flavour, its not heavy or syrupy. Extremely well done. (18/20)

2012 bottle. Pours a rich, deep brown with a moderate head in a snifter. Aroma is accents of caramel, nuts, Belgian Yeasts, figs, raisins, some floral notes. The taste are bold malts, caramel, Belgian Yeasts, clover, slight anise, figs, raisins, and leather. Great carb, sprite mouth. Not boozy at all. Very tasty and balanced.

750 ml bottle dated 2014. Pours a hazy caramel brown with formidable head. Nose is amazing layers of fruit, melon, citrus, banana, papaya, Not sure if its the hops or the malt. Similarly complex fruit in abundance on the flavour. At the same time very Belgian tasting, malty and bready. Starts really fizzy, gets really creamy as it warms and carbonation is released. Fantastic.

750 ml corked and caged bottle, No. 2013 - 182167. Quite the gusher! Hueless chunky opaque murky brown, fine creamy tan foam settles and lasts. Aroma is malty, caramel, yeasty, spicy. Taste is rich and spicy yeasty, caramel malts, dark fruitiness, vinous, almost port-ish, oaky vanilla. Livlier carbonation, medium bodied, lightly hopped. DNFL (Definitely Not For Lagerboys)
Drank at Alex and Heidi's house in Toronto. Warm red-brown with creamy off-white head. Very malty and boozy, like a strong Belgian dark ale. Some nut and spice. Body is fizzy but very smooth.

Bottle at Alex's in Toronto. Very hazy creamy brown pour with thick head. Aroma is cinnamon, spice, citrus peel, Belgian-y. Taste is similar. Quite rich but mostly Belgian flavors. Good but not my type.

2011 Grande Reserve 17-750 ml. bottle shared to snifters, displaying a murky, brown tone, with a presentable layer of brownish tan head foam, and spots & strands of lacing. The nose was malty, with caramel & toffee, light spice, and a touch of dark fruit. Mimicking the aroma notes, the taste included moderate hop bitterness, a touch of esters & oak tartness, with average carbonation, in a medium body. Alcohol lent some warmth, but was well incorporated into the presentation. With some malt sweetness & dryness to the finish, the texture tended to be less thick & syrupy as many Dark Strong Ales. Well balanced, flavorful, and rather spot-on Trappist version.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle. Hazy and murky brown with good amount of white head. Sweet Aromas of raisins and something I cant put my finger on. 
Has a good balance of sweet and bitter. Its hard to tell that it is a 10% beer. It has a lot of carbonation which keeps the taste alive. Covers the mouth with a nice taste.
Pours hazy amber, creamy tan head. Aroma is faint raisins, dates, a touch of yeasty clove. Taste is sweet, hints of raisins, finishes with a clove spiciness. Full body, creamy mouthfeel. Fantastic.

Bottle. Murky, muddy brown pour with a creamy tan head, good retention. Lots of dark fruit notes, raisin and grape, bread and yeast, vanilla and a touch of lemon zest. A touch more carbonated than necessary, and a little lighter and thinner on the palate than expected, but quite complex and tasty.

750ml cork bottle (2013-174712) poured into a snifter around 10 degrees. Pours a semi-cloudy mohagany with vivid carbonation topped by a huge creamy hazel head. On a également dagréable effluves alcoolisés, de la levure belge, des épices (anis surtout, mais également clou de girofle, muscade, piment de la Jamaïque) et du boisé (fût de chêne!). Excellent nez! Très agréable, très complexe et très intense, il est parfait! En bouche, pétillement moyen-élevé sur la langue, et onctuosité très bien au palais, cest moelleux et velouté. Généreusement maltée, mais pas tellement sucré, pain grillé, grain rôti avec léger caramel qui fait pas mal cola. Fruité et épicé, mais moins quau nez, ce qui ressort surtout en bouche est leffet du mûrissement en fût de chêne, alcool, boisé, légère fumée (tourbe) et même légère vanille. Amertume minimale, la finale est principalement alcoolisée et boisée. Tout aussi intense en bouche quau nez, complexité qui semble un peu inférieure à cause de la domination de lalcool et du boisé, mais toujours excellente, lintégration des différentes saveurs entre elles est excellente. Très gros coup de cur pour moi!

Poured from bottle into a snifter glass
 Appearance  The beer pours a very murky brownish-red color with a small foam head of an off white tan color. The head fades moderately fast leaving only a decent level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
 Smell  The aroma of the beer is massive and sweet with tons of darker fruits. The darker fruit smells are heaviest of a raisin smell, but contain other aromas of plum and fig as well. Along with the dark fruit are some rather strong smells of candied sugar as well as some smells of molasses. Other Belgian aromas of a yeasty smell as well as a decent showing of spice of a coriander, clove, and pepper aroma are there. Some banana smells and a bit of a boozy red wine smell mix with the sweeter Belgian strong dark smells nicely to produce a sweet and inviting aroma overall.
 Taste  The taste begins much drier then would have been anticipated from the nose, but does begin with many of the flavors that may have been expected. Some darker fruit flavors of a raisin and fig taste mix with a decent showing of a toasted grain and spiced flavor of coriander and clove. As the taste advances, the darker fruit fade some, but are replaced by a bit of brown sugar and molasses, maintaining an overall moderate sweetness. All the while, the roasted flavors increase some and are joined by some rum and some grapy red wine flavors. Some woody flavors also come to the tongue more toward the end, mixing the more boozy rum and red wine flavors nicely and bringing in the barrel aged flavor the would be expected from the label. A bit of a cocoa and yeasty flavor come more toward the end as well, and with them bringing a light spicy earthy flavor, to overall in the end, leave a darker fruity, more lightly sweetened, Belgian strong dark flavor with a nice heavy warming feel to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the slightly thicker side with a carbonation level that is higher and pricklier. The bigger body is nice for the darker and boozy flavors of the beer all while the prickly carbonation is fantastic for the fruity, yeasty spiced, and sweet flavors of the beer. Overall, well done.
 Overall  like most of Unibroues beers, this is a very enjoyable and quite tasty brew with lots of robust flavors that blend rather well with each other. A very tasty Belgian strong dark.

October 2nd, 20120 - Unibroue was a keystone to my early beer drinking days. Plowing through all four of the core bottles, I learned several important lessons about craft beer which I carry with me today. First, craft beer is good. Second, different styles taste differently. Third, foreign countries make excellent craft beer. Simple lessons, yes, but while they may be parsimonious, they are profound, and essentially the hooks by which I was caught into this now admittedly expensive hobby. Opening the Unibroue 17 was a kind of lap marker, pointing me back to those college days where I had to scrape together enough money to enjoy half a bomber per week, but it was always money well spent, as is the 17. Cherrywood and a light, parmesan cheese umami form around a core aroma of cherry sourness, wet moss and a tang of greek yogurt. The scent is like a sour, but not quite so dramatic, and a little more tanginess than Id expect in a sour. While the aroma is effervescent, and even bubbly with its quirky mixture of scents, the taste is a little flatter and staid - more parmesan and yogurt, with herbal touches akin to dill and parsley. These are grouped with the taste of gingerbread and clove, though all of it subtle, and never too loud or cloying.

Après en avoir dégusté plusieurs bouteilles au cours des trois dernières années, (mêmes des bouteilles vieillies), voici un espèce de résumé de mes observations:
Olfactif: Tous les échantillons présentaient un nez complexe aux arômes de caramel, dépices, de cannelle, de clou de girofle, de menthe poivrée, de mélasse et de sucre de canne. Des notes danis, de réglisse et de cerises sont également présentes. Un nez extrêmement complexe, aromatique et puissant.
Visuel: De couleur brune, très floue, avec beaucoup de particules de levure. La mousse est de moyenne à abondante, beige, effervescente et persistante. Elle colle également très bien au verre. 
Gustatif: Le poivre sort énormément en attaque avec des notes de tabac, laissant ensuite place au caramel. Leffervescence est continue en bouche. Lalcool est marquée et enveloppante. Les saveurs ont beaucoup de difficultés à sinstaller a cause de la trop forte présence des notes de poivre et de tabac. Dommage, ça aurait pu être une grande bière. Ça reste néanmoins une excellente bière, sauf quelle aurait intérêt à être plus explosive en saveurs.

Presentation: It was poured from a corked and caged 750ml bottle into a tulip glass. The bottle lists the abv at 10%.

Appearance: The body has a deep brown color with dark crimson highlights. A thick and creamy off white head stands on top. This head hangs on very well and leaves nice lace patterns on the glass.

Smell: There is an interesting blend of sweet malts, dark fruits, grapes, funky yeast, and earthy old leather. The 10% abv is very noticeable but in an inviting way. Just noticeable underneath everything else I pick up some very slight herbal hop notes. 

Taste/Palate: The flavor notes are well blended and backed up with some serious but tasty booziness. Just like the nose suggests it has dark fruit and wine like grape notes with malty sweetness and earthy yeast. Hops are light and add a touch of leafy spice and herbal character off in the distance. The palate has a firm full feel and body with plenty of carbonation to keep it lively and drinkable.

Notes: Overall this is an outstanding and very well made big Belgian Dark Ale. It ages very well and brings lots of interesting complexity to the palate. Its too bad that this is only a limited one time brew.

A steady pour into my Bruery Tulip produces a two finger thick, light amber tinged, tan color. The beer is a concentrated amber color that shows a mostly clear, red-plum hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells of dark fruit notes like plums, red grapes, a savory raisin note, and perhaps a touch of dates. There is a rich maltiness here that has caramelized overtones to it, touches of English biscuit, and some brown bread like character and, in combination with a light woody note, adds some savory character to this beer. 

The beer has a soft carbonation that provides some nice prickly character, and the body has a medium fullness to it though it lightens up pretty well in the finish. The finish has a nice savory character to it, rich concentrated plum notes, brown grain crackers, a light woody, toasted oak, and a touch of spicy, oaky, astringency. Clove features prominently here, and there is an earthiness to the spice character that is a bit like coriander, and this also has some cardamom like notes to it. Hints of chocolate mix quite well with dark fruit notes, touches of roses, and perhaps some carnations. The finish has quite a phenolic spiciness to it as the beer warms up. 

The best part of this beer is that it is very well balanced, and quite integrated. The complaint, though it isnt very significant, is that there isnt really anything that pops here; the beer is a low rumble of goodness, with quite a bit of complexity, but is so well balanced and integrated that everything just works.
Hands down the best beer I have ever tasted. Unibroue make a number of high quality beers, but this is easily their best effort.

Single bottle purchased from Zyn Liqour in Calgary, AB on 07/20/2012. EDITION: 2011 GRANDE RÉSERVE 17, BOTTLE # 2011-11038. Colour: Deep dark brown with distant amber. Medium solid off-white head. Nose: Deep malt that boasts spaghetti and meatballs aroma. Wet forest earth, distant mint, pecan pie filling. Complex but balanced. Taste: Medium-light sweet, medium-light bitter, medium sour. Initially hints of cola. A dryed malt middle that spits some spice, cinnamon and cranberry. Sour-bitter swirl late with again a whisping dryness on the finish, clearly a product of the high ABV. For the most part - elegant, aside from a bit too dry.

Sample on tap at Festibière (Quebec City). Pours hazy amber with little white head. Nice aroma of red fruits and Belgain yeast. Taste is well blanced sweet. Some warming alcohol. Very drinkable despite the 10% abv. Great beer.

This was a special bottle brought in by the brewer to Bottleworks for a tasting. Aged on cherries. Hazy tanish with a red tint, quick head dissipation.  Smell red fruit and strong spicy apple. Taste slight tart cherry, oak and plum. Melds well, earthy finish. Nice.

Hazy dark brown/amber pour with medium sized off white head. Aroma of fruit, vanilla, oak, and yeast. Taste of plums, caramel, vanilla, oak aging present and a hint of red wine. Slightly sweet and a tartness present as well. This bottled labeled Grand Reserve 17. Had the original Unibroue 17 and I swear that it was slightly different, being a little sweeter, fruitier, and smoother with a little less tartness, but ratebeer claims this is the same beer. From memory only the original would probably score 2-3 points higher. Very good berr though nonetheless.

Oaky sweet aroma. Pours a cloudy brown-amber color with an active tan head. Tastes sweet, tannic, slightly bitter, and finishes dry. Flavors of oak barrel, figs, plums, dark malts, hops, and has a wine-sweet finish.

Purchased bottled and poured on June 27, 2012. Strong fruit aroma, mainly figs with a hint of cherry and spices. Dark amber color with a large head that falls fairly quickly, little lacing. Medium body with perfect amount of carbonation. The flavor hits the palate slowly, with mild spice and strong fruit flavoring. Comes across same as aroma. Aftertaste has a strong Oak flavor as expect, with slight alcohol taste as it warms.
Not bad, not great.    Ive had better unibroue offerings thou.  Many a brew later, I bid myself goodnight.
A very good style, grand reserve version, brown pour with yeast and fruit on the nose and a nice alcohol and sweet flavors.  A tasty strong ale.

A-- Poured a dark brownish orange color with a nice tan head. Got a fluffy one finger head on it and leaving a thick lacing on the glass. Good carbonation.

S-- Smells sweet and somewhat boozy. A little bit of a yeast smell. Lots of fruit in this

T-- Get a bit of orange and then the yeasty sweet taste. Sugar and booze as well.

M-- Still has good carbonation but it is thick and chewy. The the alcohol feel to it as well. Does burn a bit going down.

D-- One. Plain and simple. Not bad but when you think of Unibroue you generally think La Fin and how excellent that is. This is good but a bit overboard on the yest and the alcohol smell. A lot going on in this. I can see where this beer could grow on you after a bit. The 10 % is very apparent from the beginning.

750 ml bottle with label reading grande reserve 17 bottled 2011. Pours hazy deep copper brown with a large soapy frothy off white head that fades to a sudsy film. Aroma is somewhat tart like dried cherries and figs along with subtle woody vanilla and grapes. Taste shows the oak well with hints of grapes and faint vanilla flavors and tart dried fruit of cherries and plum and gentle yeast in the finish as well as some nice spice. Palate is full with a good carbonation that is gentle and finishes chalky dry. Solid beer, very nice with awesome flavors!

Bottle at TPSA. Pours a rich dark brown with a light head -- somewhat cloudy. Nose was molasses and chocolate buttercream frosting; the same stuff showed up on the tongue, in an amazingly smooth, rich, and almost viscous brew. FInish was extremely long and smoky cocoa. Yeah.
From a 750 ml bottle. A very dark ale with a light tan head. What a delight this is! It tastes of malts and of dried fruits. A very complex flavor profile. A beautiful BSA.

750 ML bottle purchased at Liquor barn in Redding, CA. THE POUR / APPEARANCE: Pours a deep brown with an fluffy off-white head. Good and proper meniscus for the style.AROMA / BOUQUET: definitive French Oak, wonderful nuttiness, allspice. TASTE: Lovely woodiness in the beer- wood barrel fermented. Deep, rich, caramel, with a light smokiness, almost a tawny port-like quality. Hop bitterness is pronounced, but not overly so. PALATE: Woody smokiness, proper mouthfeel for this kind of ale. For those cigar lovers out there, this would make an excellent pairing. Enjoy with smoked meats, Port Salut cheese, or even as a dessert ale- its that sumptuous! This is one of Unibroues finest. Vive a la Quebec!
750 ml bottle - pours clear amber with tan head and nice lacing.  Nose is cherry and wood.  Flavor adds alcohol and barley.  Very complex and numbing.  Sweet and sour.
Bottle to taster at Natifest. Looks solid; brown with off-white head. Smells doughy and spicy. Tastes good; plum, fig, and burnt-orange flavor. Average on the palate. Good beer!

Pour out of 750 mL marked Grand Reserve, dark ruby red pour with nice off white khaki head, aroma brought notes of oak, sour cherry, some dark fruit with fig and plum, some candi sugar notes, touch of nice caramel, molasses notes, some slight bready and yeast notes as well.  Taste is rich, sweet red ripe cherry, dark berry, some plum and fig notes, hints of candi sugar go into some very slight oak, some nice spice and earthy elements, hints of a bready quality with some molasses and caramel sweetening it out towards the end.

Bottle 2011-28799
Reddish brown colour, off-white head. Aroma of wood, fresh oak, vanilla, light spice, somewhat sweet malts. Wood flavour, sweet malts, caramel and barley. Finish wood and spices, some lingering sweetness.
(From 750 mL bottle shared @ ZZT IV. Trade by doubled77. Thanks!)

2011 Bottle (117412) - Pour is murky dark amber / brown with a modest frothy off white head. The nose is dark fruits, caramel and toffee, raisins, and baked bread. The flavor profile has a slight vinousness out of the gate, with more dark fruits, raisins, plums, and sweetness from the caramel notes - there is a bit of bitterness here - with mild alcohol notes. This is a nice belgian dark strong - there is a touch of cream from the head, and mild oaked notes present here as well.

Burns the nse subtlely with elements of wet lamb and cherries.  Brnt amber appearance with milky head.  mild sexual spanish lace.  Medium thickness.  Apple, citrus, and  raisin ride a back of lightly toasted malt.  Subtle cranberry and bitters ride to the end of this delicious treat.
[750ml bottle, courtesy of cgarvieuk] Deep amber. Yeasty, peppery aroma. Big carbonation. Farmhouse. Sweet yeasty breadiness. Sweet and floral. Peppery tang. Very nice indeed [06072012]

Unibroue 17 Grande Réserve . 750 ml C+C bottle into a goblet.  #2011-91282, Best before 12-12-2016.

A - Clear dark brown body. Lets a good bit of light through. Nice and dense off white head with fantastic lacing and retention. 

S - Tons of spice. Cinnamon, brown sugar, caramel, maple syrup, and candied plums and raisins. A touch of earthy and bready yeast. Light oak and vanilla tannins.

T - Christmas spices lead into dark candied fruits and maple syrup. The finish is yeasty with notes of bready malt, bananas, and spicy esters. A light oak presence with a faint alcohol warmth. Mouth feel is well carbonated but medium bodied. 

O - This is an excellent beer. The dark fruits and caramel/brown sugar work really well off of the spicy and banana strong Belgian yeast strain. A beer worth cellaring for sure, seems like it would evolve really well over time.

Grande Reserve 2011. Clear reddish brown with a modest, but fairly resilient, off-white head. Delicious aroma of wood, caramel, dark fruits, Belgian funk, and spice. The taste is a nice blend of moderately sweet and woody with a dose of funk. Medium bodied, smooth, and slightly dry. Very nice.
A wonderful beer. Opaque brown and oatmeal-beige cap. Sticks like a really sticky thing, to the inside of the glass. Aroma of spices and old, wet wood. Taste is spicy yeast and raisins. Yummers.

750ml bottle ---> snifter -----> my damn mouth- So well constructed.  So smooth.  Probably the smoothest 10% beverage Ive had the pleasure of drinking.  The oak, those esters, that slicks mouth feel all combine quite well.  Such a subtle hitter.

From notes: Bottle #2011-89299, poured into Trappist glass.  Poured hazy nut brown with some ruby red at the base of the glass.  Thick, creamy 2-finger bone-colored head.  Sweet aroma, with notes of caramel and fruit, and light notes of wood and yeast beneath.  Medium-thick, with a nice, full body.  Flavors of sweet candied fruit and bready yeast with a nutty note in the back.  Creamy note to the finish.  As it warms, the wood appears up front and the nutty note becomes stronger as well.

2011 Bottle, Grand Reserve.  The house yeast shows up in the nose along with some spices blended with apples and other like fruits.  Tastes of spice and bananas mixed with rich malts and the distinguishing yeast that stands out.  No notice of woods or oak.  The finish dries out with a little burn.  Its the yeast flavors that hold me back from a higher rating.  Still, a great beer.

Pours a cola color with a HUGE khaki head. Aroma is extremely spicy, strong scent of cloves and ginger, and a hint of cherry as well. Taste still has the ginger clove combo but its not as strong as I expected it to be, maybe the oak makes it mellow, hints of vanilla and cherry as well, complex belgian ale. This is great.
Opaque brown,lasting tan head.Nose of spicy yeast/alcohol.Tart spicy yeast palate, fruity and effervescent.Yeast and alcohol both overpower
750 ml bottle. Pours a clear red/brown with very light head. Aromas of candied fruit, ginger, and roasted malt. Strong bitter flavors. Spicy: ginger, cloves, allspice. Malty and warm.

750ml bottle, labeled as Grand Reserve.
Reddish brown body with some off-white head.  Nose of dark fruit, caramel, and spicy Belgian yeast.  Flavors of oak, vanilla, cherry and other dark fruits, and the signature Unibroue yeast.  I have a feeling the flavors will better meld together with time.

750 mL bottle, 2011 bottling.  Pours a darkish caramel color with a yellowy head.  Apple aroma followed by cloves, bubble gum, other spices.  Red apple, clove, caramel flavors, raisin, with Unibroues usual yeast, hints at and molasses, cocoa, anise.  Has a nice full palate and a dry finish.  Quite a tasty strong dark ale here.

6 July 2012, bottle at cagarvie's legendary tasting. Faintly pinkish brown, clear, no bubbles. Nose is sugary, alcohol, peppery, faintly vegetable, maybe peppermint (?). Thin body and faintly fizzy. Belgian strong ale with bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2014 bottle at home ... light hazy copper ... thin bubbly white head ... soft floral pine yeastyness ... big pine zezt  ... soft yeast ...big sweetness ... light saison tones ... juicy ... very juicy ... 

Bottle at bow tasting... Copper... Thin white lacing... Soft sweet fruits... Juicy fruits... Soft toffee... Big sweet sherbert banana... Light pineapple linger 3.5

2011 bottle. Pours a dark golden amber colour with a fair beige head. A lovely sweet and spicy aroma with caramel, peppermint, chocolate, oak and alcohol. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation, light CO2 prickle and a foamy mouth-feel. Lingering candy sugar and white pepper.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled in December 2010.  Pours very hazy reddish brown color with a very nice 3 finger dense light khaki head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Some very nice thick soapy lacing clings to the glass, with a good amount of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of big raisin, prune, grape, caramel, toffee, molasses, earth, tobacco, toast, and light herbal.  Fantastic and highly complex aromas with great balance.  Taste of big raisin, prune, apple, caramel, toffee, toast, molasses, earth, tobacco, herbal, light chocolate, and yeast spiciness.  Lingering notes of dark fruit, caramel, molasses, toffee, toast, earth, light chocolate, and yeast spices on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic balance of flavors with huge complexity.  Medium-high carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a nice creamy and fairly slick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden with pretty much zero warming present after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic Belgian strong dark ale!  Huge complexity and great balance of flavors; and very smooth to sip on.  Looking forward to trying the Grande Reserve.

Bottle 2011 number 84900 .... Deep reddish pour off white head .... Aroma is of dark fruity yeast, light spicy coriander and orange peels..... Taste is spicy and of dark fruit, caramel malts, dry oaky aspects and spices, notably cinnamon, ginger and a light peppery/coriander bite .... finishes dry with some spices lingering .... very fresh and well put together abv hidden pretty well just a hint of heat with the spicy bite

This was the reissued Grande Reserve 17 edition, shared by jjfoodie. The beer pours a brownish color with a white head. The aroma has a ton of dark fruit in it, as well as a little bit of toffee. The flavor is a little more complex, with some oak and cherry notes complimenting the cherry and alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. 

This bottle was drank alongside an original Unibroue 17, which had developed more dark fruit and yeast components during its aging period.

Bottle @ZZT IV: 2011-28799:
Quick disappearing off white creamy to light tan ish head on top of a hazy amber colored beer.
Smell lots of oak and wood, some spices and some barley malts.
Taste lots of oak, spices, some sweeter barley malts, warmth of alcohol, light smokey touch, nicely balanced.
Aftertaste is spicy, with smokey malts, herbs and a touch of wood.
Medium carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a creamy texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle - very bog thick head, very dark brown/amber color, complex Belgian yeast spice & oak aroma and flavor, mild fruit esters, smooth oaky finish - extremely complex beer, I am not good at describing this beer in words, other than to say it is excellent!

Dark brown in hue. Head forms and quickly dissipates. Tastes a big young for oak aged but as it warms more of the stone fruit flavors come out. Benefits from some swirling in a glass. Could use some time to develop a more complex profile. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown colour with off white head. Strong aroma of grapes, vanilla, and oak. Taste is sweet fruit, lemon. Thin fading palate.

I remember this Special Reserve with no medicinal characteristics. This was poured at a good temperature with a nice sized, ligh tan head, and almost no lace. Color is a clear, dark honey amber with a couple of bubble trails. Aroma is malt, camphor, menthol, spice, wine. Flavor is like nose, sweet  followed immedietly by carbonic tang, then the other flavors. Body is good until beer warms a bit, carbonation good. Finish like flavor, tapering to a long bitter. Not a fav from Unibroue.
Whew!  Another fantastic beverage from Unibroue.  Crazy big and boozy, and very complex.  Had on tap at Lansdale Beer Fest.
75cl bottle @ ZZT IV. Hazy red-brown color, small off-white lacing. Smell almost nothing....weird... Taste lightly malts, sweetness, some alcohol and some yeast. Too much carbo, medium body.
Bottle @ ZZT4. Ruby to brown colour, small white head. Smells sweet, malty, heavy cloying sweetness, heavy. Tastes heavy sweet, very herbal, not nice. Too much carbo, medium body.

@Mondial de la Bière 2012, Montreal - cloudy brown beer with a little foam left; toasted - almost smokey - maltiness; nutty and earthy; fizzy and pretty sweet; some late bitterness; residual sugars and a long malty, nutty and gently smokey finish; very tasty
750mL shared by Brett, this thing has a coca cola note going on, its a mix of the barrel and somethign else that has a distinct taste of coca cola (original with HFCS)
Bottle thanks to jjfoodie.  Deep brown with a cream head.  Nose is sweet, dried fruits, yeast, sticky, and caramel.  Great on the palate, super sweet, light musk, heavy dried fruits.

(750ml bottle thanks to JJFoodie) cloudy medium brown with effervescent tan bubbles. Nose of oak, huge spices like cinnamon and clove and sweet malt. Taste of big spices, herbal, cinnamon, estery and well carbonated.

Pours a medium dark brown color with a slight haze and a faint red orange highlight when held to light. Good sized tightly bubbled off white head persists forever. Smells of raisins, dark sugar, caramel, clove, banana, and a bit of ethanol. Lightly spicy with a bit of red wine and vanilla. Nice nose. Taste is mostly sweet with a bit of sugary and caramel interspersed with lots of dark dried fruits. Spicy yeasty phenolics mix with a bit of warming alcohol to form a long lingering sweet finish. Over the top level of carbonation, medium body with a bubbly sweet mouthfeel. Nice tasty beer but has that signature Unibroue sameness. Caramel and dark dried fruit with too much carbonation that tries to ruin the mouthfeel. Glad I tried it, I dont think Id seek it out again.

Review #1,200.  From the 2011 batch dated 12-12-2016.  The pour is a very dark and cloudy amber with a long lasting, fluffy beige head that lingers on.  Loads of Belgian yeast and sweet malt aromas here as well as a little smoke and dark fruits. A feast for the nose. The body is medium and slick. The taste has this interesting candy sweet maltiness with a pungent dryish finale.  It was worth every penny of the $14 that I paid for it. This was a good choice for one of my milestone reviews.

750ml bottle. Poured a dark, opaque brownish plum with a huge sponge toffee head. Dark, stewed fruit aroma with some of the oak aged smell too. Little bit of Belgian yeast. Dark fruit sweet taste, with some light spice, oak and yeast. Cant taste the alcohol but it provided a nice warming sensation. Lively carbonation. Overall, one of my favorites to date.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2012 Une bouteille de la cuvée 2011 numérotée 24326 et une bouteille datée du 12/04/2007 offerte par Julien et Pier-Luc.  Le nouveau brassin ouvre le bal : jobserve une robe brune couverte par une mousse épaisse et dégénérative.  Une dentelle qui semble vouloir se dessiner sur la paroi.  Un premier nez de bananes mûres et dépices.  Une présence du chêne qui me semble être grimpé par les champignons et finement touché par la vanille.  Une levure qui porte les stigmates de la maison.  Un goût accaparé par les épices et par les notes surettes.  Des élans doux qui traversent cette marée belgo-germanique.  Une bouche bien crémeuse, légère et aérienne.  Une finale marquée par les épices et par certaines caractéristiques du chêne.  Un alcool habilement caché qui se manifeste, en fin de parcours, avec une chaude gentillesse.  La suite des choses est beaucoup plus spectaculaire.  On ouvre cette vieille bouteille de 2007 chez Yan.  À première vue, la robe est magnifique, beaucoup plus foncée que celle portée par sa jeune sur.  La mousse beige fait une remarquable entrée.  Elle est crémeuse, dense et indestructible.  Le premier nez est ravissant.  Il est fait de fruits confits avec des cerises et des raisins.  Le second et les suivants offrent une belle complexité.  Quelques notes surettes qui flottent dans latmosphère tandis que des vapeurs chocolatées qui séchappent vers les cieux.  Je note la naissance délicate de parfums de réglisse et dépices.  Peut-être est-ce le girofle qui donne cette impression de réglisse?  Des notes subtiles de la barrique qui simmiscent dans la conversation.  Sont-ce les quelques traces doxydation qui montent vers mes narines?  Les saveurs confirment cette sensation démerveillement.  La bouche est fruitée - goûteuse en cerises et en raisins confits - sucrée et aigrelette, chocolatée et épicée.  Un vrai régal.  On peut même penser ici à certaines grandes Belges.  Il y a du Rochefort, du Struise et du De Dolle dans cette mixture québécoise.  La sensation que laisse le liquide sur le palais est aussi très réussie.  Le liquide est encore bien voluptueux.  Son corps est bien présent.  Le pétillement nest pas atteint par lâge.  Les bulles sont vivantes et participent adéquatement.  La texture est bien crémeuse, presque molletonneuse.  La finale?  Une empreinte boisée sur des fruits complexifiés par les malts.  Un véritable coup de cur.  Une magnifique bouteille.  Ce soir, nous avons été chanceux.

Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a lasting cream colored head.  Aroma is wood, sweet dark fruits, clove, and some bread.  Taste is raisin, spice, wood, and just a hint of alcohol.  Lively carbonation.  Very good.

A perfect beer.  Strikingly Belgian in flavoring and spices, with nuttiness and malt flavor.  Strong but not heavy, in some ways feels like a dark tripel with the malt subbing in for the fruitiness typical of that style.  An absolute delight from a brewery that never seems to miss.

Interesting brew. Poured into a snifter from a 2011 bottle. Nearly opaque red brown with a short lived off white head. Smells of Belgian yeast, fig, raisin, vanilla. Tastes like many dried fruits, including apricot, apple, grape. Lots of subtle oak is woven throughout, creating further complexity and a wonderful taste. Finishes with black pepper. Pairs very well with strawberry shortcake!  Great beer!
Pours dark brown with highly carbed off white head very tight.  Aroma mixed fruit and sugars. Taste very much going on, alchohol...dark fruit and caramel...not bad dark strong.

750mL corked and caged, Bottled in 2011 Grande Reserve from Olive Tree Market in OB.  Clear reddish brown with moderate two finger beige head, pretty good retention.  House Unibroue yeast up front with some raisin and toasted malts. Lots and lots of clean oak notes present.  Flavor is still pretty strong with the oak, but goes really well with the Belgian yeast--almost refreshing, really, in its freshness.  A little surprising, as theres so much, and I was under the assumption that French Oak was more subtle than the heavy handed American oak.  Dry finish with bitterness peaking at a 2, a little alcohol noted.  Aftertaste of some dusty raisins, tinge of roast. Medium high carbonation with a medium body.  very solid, though pretty heavy on the oak, which didnt bother me.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 750 ml corked and caged, Grand Reserve 17 bottled in 2011. Pours amber brown with a 2" cream colored head. Very lively carbonation, lacing all around the glass. Nose is candied fruits, caramel, nutty, very Belgia-like. Taste is the same, malty with a slight earthiness, a slight bitter finish. Very nicely done. I would say this is one of the better Belgian strong ales Ive had in awhile.
Candied plums, raisins, figs, allspice on the nose. Murky brown, thick yellow head, minimal lacing.  Medium body. Flavor is less distinctly fruity. Malty with vague fig notes. Somewhat milquetoast.

750 ml cork and caged bottle, purchased from Spirits Toms River. Poured a murky muddy chestnut brown with a huge foamy light beige head that took forever to settle down. Aroma starts off with loads and loads of Belgian yeast, brown bread, fruitiness, dry chalkiness. Thin to medium body with very bubbly carbonation and slight heat on the backend. Flavor of Belgian yeast, brown bread, nutts, grains. Solid beer.
Bottle.  Aroma is sweet malts with notes of dark fruit and spicy yeast.  Palate is well carbonated and dry.  Flavor is sweet, but finishes dry.  Pretty impressive.
Bottled.  WOW!  This is a spectacular beer.  Very yeast driven aroma.  I taste a subtle raisin flavor that bounces across my tongue.  All in all a perfect beer!

750ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy mahogany coor with a fairly large tan head that falls quickly.  Aroma has some fig, raisin, spice (nutmeg, cinammon).  Taste is sweet with the spice adding a little bite.  Full bodied with a semi-dry finish.  Pretty good beer with some powerful flavors going on.

Bottle share with OmegaX
Appearance - Hazy brown, sea foam head
Aroma - Cherries, spices, floral hops, wet wood, vanilla, honeycomb
Taste - Spicy, yeast, fruity, vanilla, oak, earthy

This beer is just what I expected from this brewery. Among the complex, ambient aroma and full spicy body was that classic boozy character from Unibroue. What a treat!

A big thanks to Chipalsa for the graduation brew!! Nose is dark fruits, light oak, yeasty, clove, and orange pith. Body is cola colored with a light tan head. Medium bodied brew. Taste is a good amount of oak but not overpowering. Some unibroue yeast and spices, light fruity notes, a touch of alcohol, and some dark malts. I love unibroue, haha.

750ml bottle. Murky reddish brown body with a small beige head, poor retention.
Sweet and sour aroma: caramel, sour cherry, raisins, good dose of Belgian style yeast, tons of herbs, a hint of alcohol.
Taste is very smooth, much lighter than you would expect, a little oily, malt, distinct Unibroue yeast, spices, brown sugar, some berries, a hint of hops. A good warming effect. So unexpected, absolutely wonderful, resembles an old wine.
Phenols, spice, dark fruit aromas.  Spice, oak, orange peel, and dark fruit flavors.  Overall a very good Belgian ale.

Bottle: 750 ml
Aroma:Complex bouquet of roasted malt, hops and aromatic spice notes with vanilla. 
Appearance: Dark amber color with spirited effervescence and cream-colored neck.
Taste: Intensely malty, slightly sweet and hoppy with mocha & cocoa accents and a subtle oaky finish.
Palate: Medium body, slightly oily texture. fizzy.
Overall is a round bodied beer, full body with a nice strong flavour. I can sip on many bottle of this.

Pours with a big beige head, lots of CO2 bubbles rising. Looks murky brown with some yeast in the glass.  Taste is complex with dark fruits and spicy hops, classic Unibroue house yeast taste. Finishes dry fro 10% Can see why this won metals.  Look for my video review on YouTube or on our our Facebook page....Hops & Vines, in the next few days.
Murky brown with a tan head... Kinda raisiny dry finish big flavor, lively very fruity, strong full bodied chewy...

Pours a murky amber/brown with a medium tan head...good lacing  Aroma has subtle candy sugar and fruity notes...raisin and.  Flavor follows suit...just enough bitterness to dry out the sweetness and a bit of leather.  Mouthfeel is medium/full and the finish is malty but not too sweet.

750ml bottle. 2011 Vintage. Poured a dark amber, almost brown color with a larger sized off white head. Aromas of yeast, fruity, some wood, and some spices. Tastes of dark fruits, yeast, vanilla, caramel, and some wood.

Pours hazy golden brown. Nice head. Complex aroma of bread, banana pudding, cloves and yeast. Tastes like a dunkleweissen on steroids. Not present-day steroids though. More like roids in the late 70s. Taste is a litte musty, the french oak can be detected in the first few sips but quickly fades away. For the $$ spent, I would be more apt to buy a true belgian quad or a nice German dunkel.  Not bad, but also not that much different than Maudite. Also, my dad is a big fin du monde fan but he claims he always suffers the worst hang-overs when drinking Unibroue beers.  Hes probably just an old fart. But the guy enjoys his booze so I believe him.

Aroma of Belgian yeast and malts. Pours like thick rootbeer with an off-white robust head. Extremely clingy to the glass, and excellent head retention. Flavor of malts, yeast, and subtle fuel oil. Hot. Very nice mouth feel, but a bit astringent. Not my favorite Belgian style ale. Tasted from the bottle @ 60F.

Aargh, if I hadnt slacked off on entering my ratings I could be rating #500 for this beer. Oh well. 2011 vintage from Whole Foods Market Charlottesville. Pours a hazy copper color with a medium sized creamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of bread, yeast, wood and a tart finish. The taste is tart fruits, toffee, plum, yeast, bitter hops and wood. Full bodied. 7/3/9/4/162008 vintage rated side by side with the newish vintage. Not a full rating, but the older vintage seemed rounder, with more pronounced wood and fruit notes. Exceptional. This aged very well. 9/4/9/3/18
2011 batch.  Pours a hazy brown with medium cream head.   Aroma is lots of yeast and dark fruit.  The oak comes through in the flavor and it is slightly dry

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2013 Wow.... Im just amazed how Unibroue can keep doing good stuff after good stuff. Im drinking a 2012 bottle which is one year old right now !! ( i have a box of 12, 2 years old bottles in my cave(2011))  Wow you can really taste and smell the french Oak in there with a real good brown trapppist style beer. this beer might just be my favorite beer everrrrrrr...... I would like to describe it in details but the magic around this beer is so awesome that I will leave it as what it is ....A Masterpeice !!!

Pours dark mahogany with a fluffy off white head. Great nose showing off Belgian yeast along with some barrel influence. Full bodied with banana/esters along with dates and savory notes. Bright tree fruit emerges on the finish. Delicious!

750 ml. corked and caged bottle number 2011-117818. BBD 12/12/2016. Pours a thick, rapidly collapsing ivory head, with some lacing, over a slightly cloudy, copper (SRM 15) body.....nose is vanilla, light dried fruits (cherry, raisin, plum) hints of ginger, leading to pepper....taste is light  dried fruits (plum, raisin) initially, becoming slightly terpene, leading to a lingering finish that is slightly dry, pepper and clove dominated, with allspice hints....mouth feel light of medium, alcohol present and slightly hot, carbonation adds a foamy layer on the tongue. This is more Trappist in style than Abbey. It is relatively dry, has a light mouth feel and is more pepper/spice dominated than not. This is a nicely balanced beer with the yeast, malt and hop backbones all working together. Unfortunately the barrel is a bit harsh. BJCP 8/3/14/4/8

750ml bottle.

Pours dark mahogany with some ruby showing through the edges under a small thick tan head that leaves no lacing.

Aroma is dark and fruity but has more spices than I was expecting with some peppery notes and Belgian yeast.  Also some clean fresh oak.  The fruits are booze-soaked raisins and figs.

The taste starts wih the dark fruits but has an interesting toasty character to the malt profile.  Then the fruity esters take over and some figs, raisins and spicy oak.  The finish is a combo of sweet fruit and dry peppery spices.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and well carbonated with lots of dry oak on the palate as well as brown sugar and molasses sweetness.

This is a really nice Belgian beer from Unibroue though not one of my favorites from them.  Big, complex and woody.

(aged with french oak casks) pours muddy brown with a decent light brown head, good retention, some lacing. tons of dark fruits, light oak - much appreciated. light to medium hops - grassy, some resin. lively and soft, medium body - slightly lacking, nice grassy finish.

The usual Unibroue combo of very pronounced Belgian yeast, banana, clove, and cardamom esters, along with oak, vanilla, and white grape in the medium length finish.

Very creamy with a dense, rocky mousse of a head. It does, indeed, resemble Chimay Grande Reserve more than a little.

Smooth, very sophisticated, and absolutely delicious.

Bottle from the LCBO. Aroma is strong and sweet at the first hit from the bottle. In the glass its weaker, estery, a bit of malt. Highly carbonated - lost a bit from popping the cork. Beautiful deep red brown, with a thick lasting head. Flavour is rich and complex... Barley, definite sweetness, very smooth with a full body. Bitterness just at the finish. That 10% alcohol isnt very present. Lovely stuff.

Muddy brown body beneath a thick light brown head, but the lace did not stick. Rich dark fruit aromas accentuated by Belgian-like spices and yeast. Hints of roasted malt, oak and alcohol. Complex flavor profile highlighted by the dark fruit - fig and raisin - and spice notes. A touch of cinnamon, a decent amount of roasted coffee, and a subtle yet warming alcohol. Medium body, generous carbonation, smooth and creamy on the palate, and a short finish of sweet plum and fig.

750ml bottle, Grande Reserve. Rating #491. Extremely hazy dark brown color with a big rocky tan head. Picking up a lot of oak, very woody with some grape aromas and a certain mustiness. text: *(cuvée 2011 french oak): Créature particulière avec ses notes de Belgian Quad et les épices de levure rehaussés par le chêne poivré et la vanille. Belle bière trouble, bien cuivrée aux reflets roux et coiffée dun fin col chamois laissant une légère dentelle au verre. 750 ml bottle, 2011 edition. Pours a reddish foggy brown with a yellow-beige head. Smells strongly of caramel, belgian yeast and spices. Bottle, pours a nice light brown, aroma was very belgiany. the flavour was very, it had a good body and nice finish. the flavour was a bit dry, some cherries, also a bit herbal. Very nice offering

Arome de fruit confis, de malt et de caramel. Dun brun foncé jumelé à un collet couleur crème. Goût de caramel, fruits séchés(prunes, cerises) et de pain legèrement rôti. On ne ressent presque pas le 10% de cette bière. Tout simplement un chef-doeuvre d Unibroue.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 Complete re-rate. Scotre is for Unibroue 17 (original). Bottle (750 ml) Unibroue 17 (4+ years old) and Unibroue Grande Réserve 17 (1 year old) side-by-side.

Unibroue 17: Reddish brown with a small off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is fruity with malt, slight spices and slight port notes. Unibroue Grande Réserve 17: Reddish brown with a small off-white head and good lacing. Aroma and taste are of spices, Unibroue yeast, malt and slight fruits. Medium to heavy body. Alcohol is well hidden. Pretty decent beer but I prefer the old one. 4-7-7-3-15

Pour mon 799ième rating. Bouteille 750 ml. 10%. Cuvée 2011. Couleur brune au reflets orangée-rougeâtre. Mousse beige. Arôme de fruits confits, prunes, vin, malt. En bouche, douce, crémeuse, malt, fruits, levure Unibroue (eh oui..encore et encore. ;-)) Notes dalcool, prunes cuites. Finale avec une légère amertume et levure. Très bonne.

Pours brown, nice beige head, good foam retention, slowly diminishing. Good lacing. Smells spicy, and of Unibroue yeast, as most of their beers, fruits, malt, caramel. Bottle 750ml. [2007 Batch, 8/4/8/3/15]
Pours brown with reddish reflects, low beige head, intense lacing. Aroma is of fruits, caramel, malt. Taste is of fruits, caramel, acidity, sligth spices, bread, madeira. Palate: Medium body. Overall: Alcohol well-hidden. Nice fruits. Yeast features faded drastically.
Aroma of wood and caramel. Enduring thin head. High carb, acidulous nutty taste with caramel. A pleasant brew

Bouteille 750 mL. Cuvee 2011. Brune foncee. Nez boise avec de la cannelle. Bouche de levure, bois, girofle et du sucre blanc. Lensemble est rond mais subtile, sans grand eclat. Jadore les produits Unibroue et je me faisais surement trop dattentes.

Mild aroma but with a slight bit of oak. Taste is similarly mild, very smooth, some roasted malt and a bit of oak with the high alcohol content well hidden. Almost no bitterness. Aroma is woody and a touch spicy with notes of booze and dark fruits coming through. 750ml corked bottle pours a dirty amber color with a 2 finger off-white head that settles slowly leaving some nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is dark fruits and light roasted malts and some yeast. Pours dark red with frothy head.  Strong aroma and taste thats initially sweet followed up by a malty alcohol.  Very good reproduction of a fine Belgian ale.

aroma is amazing with lots of rum, molasses, dark dry fruit and alcohol. flavor is a nice balance of sweet molasses and sharp alcohol. smooth and creamy, with low carbonation, long sweet roasty finish.

Beautiful version of the Unibroue beer.  Pleasant spiciness to it and the traditional Unibroue flavours of taste and blend.

Presentation: It was poured from a corked and caged 750ml bottle into a tulip glass. The bottle lists the abv at 10%.

Appearance: The body has a deep brown color with dark crimson highlights. A thick and creamy off white head stands on top. This head hangs on very well and leaves nice lace patterns on the glass.

Smell: There is an interesting blend of sweet malts, dark fruits, grapes, funky yeast, and earthy old leather. The 10% abv is very noticeable but in an inviting way. Just noticeable underneath everything else I pick up some very slight herbal hop notes. 

Taste/Palate: The flavor notes are well blended and backed up with some serious but tasty booziness. Just like the nose suggests it has dark fruit and wine like grape notes with malty sweetness and earthy yeast. Hops are light and add a touch of leafy spice and herbal character off in the distance. The palate has a firm full feel and body with plenty of carbonation to keep it lively and drinkable.

Notes: Overall this is an outstanding and very well made big Belgian Dark Ale. It ages very well and brings lots of interesting complexity to the palate. Its too bad that this is only a limited one time brew.

poured into my ommegang glass.

dark murky brown with cinnamon highlights. Thick 3-4 finger fluffy eggshell colored head.

smells of sweet bread with cinamin, raisin, little hits of chocolate. the smells are somewhat muted and blended as there is a lot going on in here. as it warmed and i swirled it i pulled some hints of bourbon.

In short: A fantastic hoppy Belgian dark ale.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Many many times.  This rating for a bottle about 2 
years after the beer release
The look: Almost clear ruby-brown body topped by a medium beige head with good retention. The body becomes a bit cloudy towards the end of the bottle
In long: Nose is fruit cakes and freshly baked brown bread.  Taste of berries, raisin bread, caramel, molasses, signature Unibroue yeast, lots of earth, woody hops, tobacco leafs, light spicy notes.  It is quite something how this beer has morphed over its two first years of existence.  Very fresh it was a hop bomb (not in an american way) and the beer was kind of all over the place.  A few years later it has settled down and it now tastes like a world class not-so-hoppy belgian strong ale.  It is amazing how "fresh" this beer tastes at two years of age.  My favourite Unibroue ever.  It was very good fresh but now I think it has peaked.  If you have any left, now is the time to drink them.  As with everything else, its all about timing, because you know, even the best Monday 7am really sucks ass compared to an average Friday 5pm.

Aroma: caramel, chocolate.
Appearance: red, brown, cloudy, frothy, tan foam.

Fortunately, since it is a bottle-conditioned, Belgian ale, it improves with aging, rather than spoiling. So, it is just as good now, as it was when it was first released. Either that, or this beer has been brewed again since its first release.

T: The flavor is quite similar to the nose, displaying a very solid fruit character. There are some cherries in addition to the raisins, plums, figs, pears and probably some others that Im missing. The malt is fairly bready with a molasses-like sweetness that is quite mild.
