bottle. brown pour with marroon hints. higher carbonation.spicy aroma with brown sugar & dried fruits. taste was caramel malts, medium booze, dried fruits.active mouthfeel due to higher carbonation. good
Clean brown pour with off white head and lace. Brown sugar and a hint of yeast. Brown sugar with a semi dry finish. Medium bodied with smooth foamy carbonation. Nice beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a noticeable red tint and a thick off-white head. Aroma is rich in dark fruits (notably cherry) with touch of molasses sweetness, touch of toasted malts. Flavor is pretty smooth (relative to its 10%) and malty goodness. A little much unless shared (obviously).

Bottle split w/ Nutley kids at the Motel before going out Saturday night.  Had been sitting on this one for a couple of years.  Delicious, dark ale with plenty of fruity and spicy flavors.  Could have drank this whole bottle by myself, good thing I didnt.

Pours chestnut brown with a large beige head, very good lasting lacing.
 Rich cherry, grass, pine, molasses, and toast aromas.  Medium body, lively and creamy.  Medium sweet, lightly tart, light bitter finish.  Well balanced.

Unibroues seventeenth anniversary brew. Pours a dark brown colour with red highlights. The head is huge, beige, composed of small bubbles, lasts long, leaves a good dirty lacing and a nice coat on the top of the brew. The regular excellent Unibroue yeast is present in the aroma, with some nice herbal hop, plum, lemon and raisins. Other notes of wine, cherry tart and sourness. The palate is smooth, not too watery, but not too thick with just a little stickiness. Good wood taste with the raisins, small amount of nuts, dark malt and decent yeast. Quite a nice beer, and a great new one from Unibroue that we have not seen in a while (originally rated May 2008).

Aged bottle version.
Orange, cloudy beer with thin beige head.
Hoppy aroma with notes of alcohol, chocolate, molasses, coffee and spices. Full with notes of ageing and some bitterness. Very belgian.
Flavour with notes of chocolate, fruits, old wood and alcohol. Bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2010 750 mL bottle.  Dark reddish-brown with a thick, sticky, beige head.  A lovely beer to look at.  Sweet Belgian in the nose, without any particularly distinguishing features.  The flavour is a little left-of-centre for Unibroue, with coconut and booze being my first impressions.  Later, I discovered cherry brandy, along with other red berries, cola, and nutella.  A very interesting beer.  I wish Id purchased more than one.

750ml brown bottle, corked. Orangey brown colour with expected light haze. Thin off white head that fades to a light swirl on the surface. Wine like fruit nose, red berries, caramel and chocolate liquer. Flavour is dark chocolatey malt, caramel. Finishes with alcohol warming the throat and coating the tounge, familiar  and persistent Unibroue yeasty notes, a slight bitterness and a faint sourish, white grape note. Medium body, tingly carbonation. Gained a lot of complexity halfway through the bottle, its been a while since Ive really enjoyed a Unibroue beer like this.
Muddy red/brown pour with thick tan/creme head. Scent is booze but mostly sweet ripe fruits and berries. Hint of caramel. Taste is sweet and tart with booze well hidden.

750ml bottle poured into my snifter.

A- Murky chocolate colored body that pours with a large 2 finger + foamy, light tan head. After the pour the head builds more and more and takes a long time to settle at a nice one finger head. The glass is loaded with lacing the entire way down (a white film sticks to the glass essentially). The thick, dynamic cloudiness can see billowing about when held up to the light and bubbles can be seen rising to the top. Perfect appearance for a BSDA.

S- Smell is interesting and good. Dark fruits like plums and grapes arise first as well as a root-beer like essence.

T- Upfront is a lot of plum, some grape, and a root beer cola flavor. A hint of spiciness is added for the finish but the flavor is pretty uniform throughout.

P- Low carbonation and a smooth, yeasty, yet syrupy mouthfeel. Medium to heavy body.

O- This is an awesome BSDA. It reminds me of a Canadian version of the Trappist beers. Its complex and the alcohol is well hidden. I will definitely pick this one up when I see it again. Another great offering from Unibroue.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-06-2008 22:57:43

Bottle. 2 years old. Murky brown with decent white head. Lots of maple nut aromas, quite sweet smelling, some of that classic  unibroue belgian aroma. Taste is quite sweet. Long smooth and silky palate, good with a bit of age.

A deep amber to brown color with a large carbonated head. The aroma contains some chocolate, bananas, and spices. The flavor is rather malty with some bananas, chocolate, spices, and cloves. Overall Ive never been blown away by Uni anniversary beers but this one will do.

Crystal clear dark ruby red color. Foamy lasting head. Sweet-sour fruity aroma - green apple and oak barrel. Full rich mouthfeel, complex flavors of alcohol(sherry notes),fruity malts and sour cherry. Tastes like it should be sweet, but you get sour and dry instead. Well attenuated, dry finish. Ridiculously good. What youd get if you refermented a barley wine with brett.

750mL Bottle. Pours a dark brown body with a lot of head. The aroma is sweet malt and something else I either cant describe or dont remember. The taste is great, like most Unibrews. A great balance of yeast, spice and alcohol. Awesome brew

Great aroma. A beer you could sniff all day and come away with different, yet still pleasant results each time.  Very dark amber hue, with a nice pour and thin head that remains throughout.  A sweet taste initially, fading into a pleasant hop bite as it moves on with a toasted caramel finish.  A nice cool weather beer to enjoy slowly and appreciate the different subtleties with every sip.

@ a tasting, thanks David, pours dirty brown with a nice off-white head, aroma of cognac, grapes, cherries and citrus, flavor is sweet like candy, with some red wine, cherries, and grainy popcorn tones, sour towards the end, feels zesty. Medium to full body.

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks David C. Murky brown color. Aroma of alcohol, plums, raisins, berries and caramel. Sweet flavor of malt, plums, berries, dried fruits, honey, caramel, a bit of chocolate, alcohol, yeast and a drier spicy finish. Full-bodied.

At a tasting, thanks David, murky light brown with red taints, aroma of  red grapes, plum ripe apricot, glue ,herbs and grass, sweet malty flavour with red fruits and a strong acidity that lingers for a long time, but is not to overwhelming, medium to big body. An intriguing beer.

Bottle at a tasting: great aroma, lots of grapes, especially black grapes, a lot of port, white port as well, some caramel, some marshmallow, grapa, in the flavor rich malt, a bit of alcohol, a bit of vanilla, some strange glue like flavor, prunes and a bit of other dried fruits, cranberries, very good beer.

Pours a lacing beige head with a brown-copper body.  Aromas of bubblegum, tutti-fruiti, yeast, banana, roasted, and dark sugar.  Flavor is yeast, roasted malt, light dried fruit, dark sugar, clove, some cinnamon.  Finish has a lasting flavor and is a bit sharp.

750mL bottle.  Poured clear, medium garnet with a creamy, sticky cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up sweet Calvados enveloping warm raisins, redder fruits, and honey notes.. warmth brought out brown sugar, vanilla, and biscuity sweetness.. earthy notes and faint oxidation joined green apples on the final impression.. that character on the back is what made this stand out from many other Unibroue beers.  The flavor opened with tangy green apple and oaky notes, with raisins and warm, darker fruits rolling onto the middle.. caramel, toffee, and molasses sweetness also supported.. finished with molasses and raisins spiked with peppery alcohol and aggressive yeast.  Medium-bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. the Calvados character was interesting at first, but got in the way as the drink progressed.. balance and flow were OK.Update later in the evening.. a major dose of Nutrasweet showed up in the flavor and aftertaste, dropping the score 0.2.

Murky brown, thick creamy beige head. Aroma is spicy, funky yeast with lots of fruity fragrance. Taste is sweet fruit, cinnamon, nutmeg, yeast. Medium full body, soft carbonation. Initially something caught me off guard as unpleasent but once it sat for a minute it got better.

Bottle.  2.10.10.  Still pissed that someone... drank my 15.  So I can already tell this is going to be one of my favorite Unibroues, which is a good thing since so many taste nearly identical.  Pours a beautiful nutty clear but dark glowing brown, slight red tinge, gorgeous creamy frothy thin off-white head.  Aroma is nicely nutty with notes of brown sugar, nutmeg, holiday fruits, reminiscent of Anchor Our Special Ale, works nicely with the typical sweetness and Unibroue yeast.  Flavor follows much the same, a bit spicier than OSA, less brown sugar taste, a mix of Unibroue and OSA really, nutty, toasty, some nice oxidation notes, lightly vinous towards the finish, sharp molasses richness, quicker finish with a slight metallic yeasty aftertaste, like a Belgian brown ale, love the nuttiness.  Medium bodied, fluffy sizzling carbonation, not nearly as sticky or sugary as some other Unibroues, still quite sweet though.  I love Unibroues darker offerings, their typical sweetness and estery yeast  needs the robustness to fill out the flavors and add needed depth.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark mahongany with a small creamy off white head. Aromas are huge and very complex. Sweet malt, dark candi sugar, dark fruits, rum, oak and plenty of alcohol. Initially also a little coconut liquor though this seemed to fade. Flavours are equally huge with carmel, toffee, dark fruits, rum and some alcohol. The coconut liquor was also there initially but once again fell away. Mouthfeel was quite full and slightly oily. Minimal carbonation which most definately suits this style. Overall a great beer though definately one to sip.

Pours a dark and very hazy ruby-amber with a crazy active body and a large, thick off-white head that leaves some remarkable lacing. Aroma is sweet and malty, with great fruit notes, that trademark Unibroue yeast, and hints of tropical fruit juice and chocolate-covered raisins.  Flavour is a small step down from the aroma, but still very good nice and malty off the top, with notes of chocolate and citrus, dark fruit and yeast, and a surprising hit of hops in the finish.
From a bottle poured brown with a good amount of head.  Sweet malty flavor bit of alcohol in the finish.

Bouteille de 750 ml, vieille de près de 2 ans. Arômes assez doux de raisins et de mélasse. Très belle robe rousse et foncée, très belle mousse abondante et qui tient bien. Belle complexité en bouche, on retrouve de belles notes de chocolat, de pruneaux, de mélasse et de caramel foncé. La levure Unibroue nest pas trop présente, ce qui est très bien. La texture en bouche est voluptueuse et bien soutenue par leffervescence active. Finale assez douce et alcoolisée. Très bon!

750 ml corked bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a clear dark amber color with a frothy off-white head that laces the glass.  Aroma of dark, dried fruits (fig, raisin, plum), toast, caramel malts, candy sugar, spices, and wood.  Flavor is also led by the same dark, dried fruits, with notes of caramel malts, brown sugar, spices, and floral notes.  The booze really brings out the different flavors in this one, nothing subtle about it.  Medium bodied with a warming alcoholic finish.  Another great one from Unibroue- Im going to have to find more of their retired beers.

A cloudy brown color with a large egg-shell color frothy head, What Belgian Ale should taste like!! Oops, Its from Canada. The first time I had this Ale, it took over 4 hours to finish. I, also, had this Ale after the Pens won the Stanley Cup. For me, the most treasured Ale I own.

Bottle: &nbsp Muddy colored, very dirty caramel, dark, moderate frothy off-white head, dies quickly, spotty lacing. &nbsp Bready nose, heavy, soft dark pitted fruit spices. &nbsp Smells like yer typical Unibroue albeit not as 

heavy. &nbsp Its almost like a Triple crossed with one of the darker brews. &nbsp Soft fig, plums, and raisins on the tongue. &nbsp Bready, with that signature house yeast flavor. &nbsp I certainly respect Unibroue, very much enjoy 

their beers, but all the Anniversary brews seem to be coming out nearly the same. &nbsp Why not do a Flanders Red, or something wildly different from their normal lineup. &nbsp Anyways, this one reminds me of a blend of La Fin Du Monde 

and Maudite. &nbsp A little Triple, a little Dark Strong Ale. &nbsp Certainly enjoyable, and one I wouldnt want to pass up, but one that is easily forgetable. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp Its quite bubbley on 

the tongue, as most Unibroue beers. &nbsp Tiz somewhat alcoholic on the finish, but not harsh. &nbsp Certainly tasty, but not all that original. &nbsp Just like all the other Anniversary beers, slightly different but nothing out of the 

ordinary.

750 ml bottle thanks to my bro for sharing. Pours a dark brown red with a thick billowy light tan head. Aroma is spicy as hell, tons of clove and dark fruits, some yeast and banana. Definitely some candi sugar apparent along the good biscuity malts. Flavor starts with some strong dark fruits, getting slightly zesty and borderline citric. The spice continues to show strongly and in the swallow some booze and tobacco comes out. Medium body and a sharper carbonation. Very interesting beer, lots of stuff going on, kinda boozy but pretty good

Bottle.  Pours a brune body with a tan off white head.  Etoh latent fruit, fig, dates, and some honey notes.  Woody with wet wood and vanilla tones, licorice, and oak.  Warming with some vinous notes and a chewy malt backbone.  Great stuff.
unique bottle but rather generic flavor.  heavy carboantion and thick foamy head.  Dark with heavy malt.hop flavor.
poured brown with a nice slight off white head.  smells like wood with some sweetness.  tasted sweet cherries slight wood taste deffinately got sweeter with age.

Bottle and served in my Unibroue tulip: Brown hued with amber highlights topped by an initial frothy head and spotty lace. The aroma has notes of dark candi syrup, raisins, fig, plum, toasty and biscuity malts, earthy and woody esters with a touch of smoke and mint. Most of the hops have faded but there is some resiny and spicy vapours still around. The taste is malty, syrupy and fruity with a herbal, boozy and dusty finish. A tad oxidized but it works within the framework of the profile., a touch salty too. The mouth feel is lively and the aggressive, chalky finish with moderate warming. Overall a solid brew that is sort of like a abt/quad light. With the oxidization coming on, this is not much longer for aging. Drink now.

750mL bottle, pours a dark brown with a reddish tinge and thick off-white head. Subtle but wonderful aroma of dark fruits, malt and vanilla notes. Flavour is roasted/dark fruits (particularly black currant), vanilla and yeast at the end. Mouthful is creamy and well-balanced. A wonderful Unibroue brew.
750ml bottle. Pour  dark brown in color with full and foamy tan head. Aroma yeasty, spicy and fruity. Taste dry fruity, spicy and yeasty with dry finish.

(750 ml bottle (stamped "December, 2010) from Belfast Co-op, cellared for 10 mos. after purchase) Pours very dark rubyish brown. One finger of soft but sturdy tan head recedes to about 1/4" and stays. Deep malty aroma of brown sugar and red wine. Soft, smooth mouthfeel, lightly dryish on the back end. Lovely. Rich flavor of brown sugar, red wine and chocolate with a bit of alcohol burn toward the finish. I dug this.

A dark amber body with a off-white head.  A sweet caramel aroma with hints of dried fruits and bread.  Some alcohol was present.  Flavor had a nice sweet note initially and finished with a nice fresh baked bread goodness to it.  Finish was light and crisp.  Carbonation was moderate.  Good!

Bottle from Dr. Jekylls Beer Lab.  Dark brown pour with a white head.  Aroma is spice and hops.  Taste is dark fruit, alcohol, wood, and must.  Still has the consistently irritating Unibroue mouthfeel, though I like this better than others Ive had from them this far.

Pours brown from the 750ml. bottle with a creamy, tan head and beautiful lacing: Aroma of bananas, rasins, Unibroues yeast, and liquid multigrain bread coupled with a thick, hearty mouthfeel. I guess I can describe Unibroues 17 the same way. Some dark fruits, peppermint, and toffee and a slight alcohol burn in the finish. Drinkability: Spiced, malted, smooth. Rebuy: Its more like a one and done for me. #215 on 22112009, DG.

Bottle courtesy of Fratto. Murky dark brown pour. Smell is dusty malts with a fair amount of peppermint spice. Taste is dark fruits and is exactly like all the other Unibroues. Aftertaste is strong bitter. There is very little deviation from batch to batch of the majority of their big beers. They all begin to taste the same after awhile. I believe it is due to using the same strain of yeast for every beer they make.

thanks to Fred82 for this bottle.  Cloudy amber brown colour with an off white head.  
Taste is very complex.  So many different flavours as I continue to drink.  It starts off with the bitter bite of alcohol, nice yeast undertones with dark fruit flavours and light toffee.  Aroma is earthy dark fruits and malt along with spice.  So glad I held on to this one until number 300.  Just wish I had an opportunity to get more bottles.

Dark ambercolor, with a frothy pillowy beige head, leaving some belgian laces, nice yeasty, fruity nose of dark dried sultana raisins, figs, prunes, stewed apples, with some earthy toasted, caramelized, biscuity malt, cookie dough accents, with some light toffee, spicy nutmeg notes in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a warmth, yeasty, fruity, liquorish character, with some brandyish, faint port-like, plummy, raisiny flavors, with some hints of cinnamon, nutmeg spiciness, and with some toasty, biscuity, caramel, bready, malt accents, with some mild dark bitter chocolate, light candied orange peel notes, leading towards a warming, malty, fruity, raisiny, plummy, lingering hop bitternees finish.

Aroma is full with fruity and dusty, sweetish Unibroue yeast. Hazy, brown coloured beer with an off-white, medium head. The taste is sweet and has peach, aprikots, aples and dust. Some spice and raisiny malts. Bit dry in the end.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2012 pours a slightly hazy medium to dark mud brown with a 3-4 finger creamy beige head that fades to 1 finger after a few minutes and holds pretty well there. Bottled. Clear orange brown color, medium off-white head. Aroma of yeast, spices, bit raisin, malty. Barley wine, but yeasty and spicy, and with typical unibroue touch.

Bottele @ tasting by jbrus. a little hazy, light brown colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of fruits like raisins and apples. There is vanilla and yeast. The taste is fruity sweet with a little bitter and some spices. The aftertaste is bitter and fruity.

Hazy brown, beige head, good lace. Sweet, prune, apple, yeasty. And - what a surprise - those typical Unibroue aroma and flavours.

75cl bottle that has been sitting at 41st Ave. Liquors forever.   For some reason, I figured I would give it a try after all this time.   My first impression upon tasting this is that it tastes like Unibroue.   Their house yeast is just too distinctive to think otherwise.   It works pretty well in this case though.   The color is a darker brown with an almost purple hue and a fizzy head that has some size at first, dies, and then settles into a lasting slick with some lace.   yeast chunks also abound after a less-than-perfectly-neat pour.   Brown sugar, plum, cinnamon, rosemary; the aroma is really what I want to call "brightly fruity" with some herbal spice in there too.   Sure, there is a more liquorous dried fruit quality, but generic berry with a light strawberry hint and some passion fruit are there too.   As much as I get out of the nose, the flavor seems to be more straightforward, with a sweet fruitiness and drying alcohol in good balance.   Spices seem to be giving a lot here as well; but who knows how much of that is the yeast.   I want to say rosemary, but I think that is just what is on my mind.   There is a woody dryness and some tobacco in the finish, with light bitterness and vaguely muted hop flavor that is more of a token than anything meaningful.   The body is on the light side, with typical Unibroue fizz and a healthy alcohol bite that dries out the tongue and helps scrape the residual sugars from the palate.   As much as there is in this that I want to scrutinize, namely the spice and roughness, this is a really interesting beer that manages to come together in a pretty drinkable package.

Poured from 750, darker brown with reddish hue and creamy tan head.   Nose of bananas. raisins, yeast, and bread.  Very thick feeling in the mouth, almost like a milkshake.  Spicy and malty with a smooth finish.

Dont get me wrong; this is not a bad beer.  This is a hazy brown beer with a fizzy feel to it.  Has a smell of over ripe fruit and a somewhat pungent taste of raisins.  I would much rather have this than most any other grocery store beer.  I just wouldnt call it outstanding.  It is a good beer for the price point.

Pours a clear bodied dark caramel color with lots of bubbles along the side and a decently crowned head. Aroma is mild dark fruits, cherries, yeast, vanilla, oak. Body is lively. Taste is mildly sugar

Corked and caged 750.  Rich caramel malt nose, cherries and oak.  Very little alcohol, well-blended and classy.  Deep ruby-brown body and hazy with a creamy tan head.  Tastes of wood with cherry and vanilla, lightly sour and acidic.  Earthy, dark caramel, brown sugar, faint toffee.  Smooth and slick malty body, rich and luxurious, very nice!

Cloudy, copper appearance with a small, off white head and sparce lacing.  Yeasty aroma shifted to soft fruit and toffee.  Earthy, sweet, caramel malt taste with spices and dark fruit accenting the yeastiness.  Alcohol is upfront and lingers through to the aftertaste.  Full bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel with a long lasting finish.

BB 12-10.  Pours an opaque, murky, muddy, chestnut color with a full, creamy, frothy, beige head which is mostly lasting and leaves some frothy, Belgian lace.  Nose is nice and fairly complex; almost fruit cake-like with plenty of doughy yeast and fruity notes of dates, figs, blueberries, and raisins with other notes of dark chocolate, bundt cake, anise, and lots of baking spices (nutmeg, allspice).  Very similar flavor but more cake-like than anything else; the yeast is still very doughy, not quite bready, but less fruity than the nose.  Other notes of dark chocolate, faint coffee, anise, still lots of nutmeg and allspice, pecans, and lighter fruit notes of dates and blueberries.  Palate is near perfect with a full body, mild warmth, creamy/velvety/round feel, and a soft to lively carbonation.  Finishes with some light earthy bitterness, coffee notes which adds some light bitterness, dark chocolate which is also lightly bitter; a completely malt forward beer but finishes with a moderately low bitterness in a long progression leaving some cake and baking spices on the tongue.  Maybe it is the fact that I waited more than a year to try this one but everything was put together very well in this one.  It was complex with plenty of malt and yeast but still managed to create a nice bitterness in the finish which complimented the rest of the beer.  Not quite as good as 16 but still a very nice BSA.  Unibroue never fails to disappoint.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark amber with a sturdy, frothy off-white head. Aroma of malt, spice, chocolate, and hints of licorice. Heavy, full body with a creamy, smooth finish. Very good Belgian strong, but the Unibroue 16 was much better.

It poured a dark reddish liquid with a big foam that left a medium sized lacing. It had a smell of yeast, red berries and various fruits. It had a fruity taste of yeast and a warm alcoholic finish. Felt dry in my mouth. A very nice beer.

Bottle 750ml. Aged 6 months piror to tasting. Poured dark brown (virtually black) with a tinge of red and a large, dense, frothy, lightly tanned head which was fully lasting. A very strong and complex aroma with dark chocolate, rasins, blueberries, dates, figs, caramel, pepper, allspice and spiced gingerbread. Flavor was a light bitterness with rum & raisin chocolate, currents, blackberries, plums, roasted notes, ginger powder, hints of caramelized figs, a touch of coffee and a warming finish. Remarkably well balanced; beautiful contrast in flavours. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, a lightly syrupy texture and a long length finish.

Pours hazy brown, white head poor retention. Pleasant aroma very rich and bready. Subtle fruit notes. very nice.  Very complex. Kind of fruity, Malty, bready. But it is very alcoholic tasting. Kind of detracts from the palate. Not bad, ..

The smell is quite an assault on your nose, all I can think of is something that has been stored in a plastic container for too long. Malt in a bag?? Dark and thick, not too much head, but a light rign of bubbles is always present. Tastes strongly of medium flavoured malt and the yeast is prickly to the tounge. Very strong aftertase of the malt, its quite nice and fades away evenly. A great flavour combination but not quite as appealing as their regular brews.

Bottle. Aroma of tropical fruit esters, bready malt, brown sugar, Unibroue yeast. Though darker and maltier than other recent anniversary beers, the flavor has a spicy yeast character typical to their anniversary ales in particular. This is coupled with more of those unusual tropical fruit notes (unusual in that theyre obviously not from hops) and juicy caramel malt. Another more than solid brew from these guys.

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Murky brown pour with a tan head that disappears quickly. Aroma is very sweet and loaded with caramel and fruit flavors. Flavor is the same. Very sweet and fruity at the beginning with lots of raisins and sweet malts. Alcohol is hidden well. Finishes smooth and sweet.

I expected a darker beer, and this one was not as complex as I was hoping for. Was in short supply when it came out, tried several bottles. I was wanting a dark or amber brew and this was definitely too light for me. More like La Maudite. Still a great brew though, but I wouldnt say it aspires to greatness.

750ml Bottle. Poured a dark hazy coppery brown with a long lasting tan head. Nose has notes of caramel, raisins, brown sugar and mixed spice with a tiny hint of alcohol at the back. The flavour has a great balance between sweet and savoury with elements of toffee, brown bread, dates, malt and spices. Full bodied, lots of carbonation and a long finish, this is a classic Unibroue ale that is definitely worth getting hold of while its still around. One of their best.

Great smell. Has an overtone of a very organic ale, hard to describe. Taste wise, is a rich but subtle hint of flavoring, anywhere from citrus to pear even. As said, hard to describe, but really good. Happy as hell I got it.

Decent abbey ale.  Had a lot of great stouts before this so its rating might be low.  Aroma is of sweet malt with slight spice.  Flavor a little bit more of the sugary malt coming out with spice and fruit.

Bottle.  Pours a murky brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of spices, light fruits (particularly honeydew melon, cantelope).  Flavor is similarly fruity with lots of melon rind and soft melon with a yeasty finish.  Kind of odd tasting but drinkable.  Very different from the other Unibroue anniversary ales, which was surprising.  
7/4/7/3/14 Ɠ.5/5)

750ml Bottle. Pours hazy brown with an average, light brown head, with lasting lacing. Aroma is heavy malt , caramel, hop , heavy yeast with notes of alcohol, Full bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish. Long duration, moderate sweetness.

Bottle. Poured a murky dark copper. Nose was malty spicy and sweet. Flavor was a very pleasant surprise. Nicely carbed with a rochefort 10 quality to it. Dark fruits, cherries, chocolate, with a hint of the abv. Nice depth of flavor, very drinkable.To date the best Unibroue that I have tasted.

This beer is delicious.  I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617 this evening to commemorate his 300th beer review on RB.  What a nice beer to celebrate the occasion with.  He picked this up at Holiday Market in RO and it certainly didnt disappoint.

Always a good thing when you pop the cork and its smoky off the bottle :)  It poured a really pretty garnet/mahogany color with a steady thick tan head (really, 15 minutes later this head is still hanging out and ready to roll).  Aroma was intense, different, and really exciting.  Its really bitter on the nose, candlewax (odd, but its the truth), cider, sour, carame;, and chocolate.    It tastes incredible.  Really something different for a Belgian style ale.  Its almost like a combination brown ale and Belgian...really something great..  Its got a mildly heavy mouthfeel - maybe a tad syrupy.  Its got a bit of the alcohol burn on the finish, but it doesnt distract too much from the greatness that is in this bottle.  Its creamy. and has a bit of a punch.  

Cheers to Unibroue for 17 epic years of brewing some of the most tasty beverages on earth.

300th BEER RATING!!  Soo.. I shared the 750ml with my best beer bud MereLikesBeer. This stuff is everything about why I drink beer. Its epic. The aroma is caramel, vanilla, bready, etc. The flavor is even more complex, with tons of caramel, dark fruits, and some chocolate on the finish. Very good pick for my 300, and amazing beer from an awesome brewery. Cheers!

This was my preference over the 16 and the Terrible at a recent tasting. Rich, spice and fruity esthers draw you in. I could drink this any day of the week but it was particularly enjoyable standing round a fire on a cold August night.
Great belgian strong ale as always unibroue is a favorite of mine. Complex and delicious

750ml bomber:  The cork comes out of the bottle with a loud "pop".  This one pours an almost opaque dark amber color.  There is quite the large beige head on it.  It leaves quite a bit of lacing.  Nice nose to this one.  Caramel, brown sugar, yeastiness and earthiness are the main components.  The taste is very good.  It is a complex taste, with only a few flavors distinctly coming out on top.  Slightly sweet and spicy with a hint of dryness to the finish.  Another winner.  It was a good choice for #1300!

Bottle.  Pours hazy brown with an average, rocky, light brown head, lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (nutty, cookie, caramel, light hop (perfume), heavy yeast (earth, barnyard) with notes of alcohol, brown sugar, oak, and mushrooms.  Full bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

2/26/2008:  Unibroue 17 smells lightly spicy and fruity and a bit like a roggenbier.  It tastes slightly sweet and has a great beldn of malt, fruity spice, and bitterness.  It has  a dry rye-like finish.  The beer is brown in color and slightly cloudy.  The brown medium to large foamy head leaves great lacing on the glass.  Very good!
750 mL corked and caged bottle (10% alc./vol.) shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #346 for this beer.

750 ml bottle from BevMo Salinas.Wonderful smelling nose of banana, candi sugar, toffee, and golden raisins. Hazy dark brown with a big, heavily lacing beige head. Flavor is raisins, sugary toffee, spiciness, and a hint of molasses. My favorite so far of their brews.

Bottle- A deep murky brown/orangey pour, with a frothy and thick mocha cap. Good lace left behind. The nose is just incredible on this beer. Huge on yeasty esters, loads of perfume and banana. Like banana cream pie, with nutty malts and deep dark pit fruits. The flavour profile is sweet but balanced. Loads of banana, berries, floral hops and tart yeast. Heaps of spices round it out. This is creamy and very drinkable for the weight. A complete surprise and a real treat. Like banana cream pie in a glass.

This poured out a dark and mysterious brown fluid, capped by a rocky off-white head of between and two fingers thickness.  Ive rarely seen a head like this, as it stayed and stayed and stayed like the thing that wouldnt leave, and as well the longer it hung around the creamier it became.  Great stuff, this.  The aroma was much more gentle that expected, featuring what I guess to be dark fruits and some spices.  Tasted like dark fruits and spices, too (dont ask me which ones, as Ive not got a bloody clue).  Also "tastable" (is that a word?) was the alcohol.  Solid mouthfeel and a nice finish make this a pleasure to drink.  Good thing Ive got another of these in the beer fridge, right next to a Unibroue 16.  Yeah, I screwed up and drank this one out of order.
Smells like sweet nuttyness.  Dark amber lovliness with a creamy light headiness.  Chocolatey, brandy, and brulee flavorness.  Not lingering but yumminess.  Very good beerness.

***review from Aug 4, 2008***
Ive finally manned up and opened this sucker - I figure that if Im on 3 hours of sleep now is the time.
Pop of the cork gave a nice beer smoke that I inhaled - love that beer smoke! Poured out a nicely sized slightly foamy tan head that gives out lots of ropy lacing throughout - retained wonderfully - remember, this is 10%, and the whole thing sits on top of a mid to mid dark brown brew which was a colour that I had not expected. This beer looks awesome! The aroma is quite different than the what is usually expected from Unibroue: softer spiced yeast, almost completely lacks the standard Uni smell, soft raisin, I have no idea what the malts are here - its almost a Rum Butter" ice cream aroma, the sweetness is somewhere between brown sugar and burnt sugar, dark candylike fruit... so much here on the aroma. The taste is different as well: sweet, spicy, mystery malts that I will just assume are there, plum, faint chocolate (maybe - I found this same idea in the aroma but could not give it to chocolate), something that is nutty without being nutty, condensed caramel, brown sugar, sour cherry just hit for the first time, seems smoky but isnt - this beer is just one big freaking mystery. The mouth feel is really good now, my marks keep climbing. Solid spice through out, over medium bodied, fluffy carbonation, nothing too harsh on the aftertaste: the spice has staying power but its not over the top. Interesting beer that is probably not worthy of a 4.2, Ill get another bottle or two. Unibroue has come up with something different and that is good.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2012 Strong, rich Belgian, though not very interesting nor complex. Pours dark and attractive, with a retained white head. The Belgian yeast aroma checks in. Above average mouthfeel, it is drinkable, but can use some hook, like spice or fruit. Much better with food.
2011 very nice, smooth, upgrade.
Big aroma of yeast. Flavor is huge yeast, some spice, carbonation is somewhat heavy on the palate. Some decent Belgian characteristics, but not very exciting.

750 mL bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar (Escondido, CA).  Pours a dark plum color, bordering on brown.  Two fingers of off-white head quickly dissipates to a thin but persistent layer.  Aroma is complex and difficult to separate the components but here goes: yeast (less than many others from Unibroue), banana, plum, sweet grainy-ness, and some level of spice (clove and ginger?).  Flavor is similarly complex with wood, caramel, dark fruit, and a very nice level of molasses-like sweetness.  There is also a distinct ash/campfire flavor toward the end.  The 10% ABV is almost completely concealed.

Bottle shared with a friend. Very good lacing on the glass with a potent head. Sweet with slight sourness on the palate, giving way to blackberries, dates, yeast and molasses. Very nice brew, and one of the best Ive had from this brewery.

750ml corked bottle opened June 2009.  Deep. opaque, amber brown color, with a substantial beige head.  Lots of dark fruit flavors.  Some spice as well, I want to say cinnamon, but it could just be the yeast.  Raisin, cognac cherry, this is really deep and complex.  The alcohol is pretty present, not unlike a Belgian Quad or Abt.  Great.

Pours a dark brown with a dense thick tan/off-white head.  Aroma hits the nose from the bottle with a strong sweet and yeasty note. with notes of cherry, light vanilla and spices. Flavor is a strong sweet dark cherry note with some light estery flavors, lots of sweet caramel malt, slight chocolate flavor at the very end and alcohol does come through a little as well at the end. Density is great and very heavy of sugar, carbonation is high and the head is just wicked, leaving behind a very thick and dense coating on the glass. Another fine anniversary ale by Unibroue and one of the better ones to stock up on while you can.

Bottle.  Sweet yeasty aroma.  Deep mahogany body, thick beige head.  Flavor is sweet and spicy, with ripe fruit, banana, and caramel.   A little too sweet.   Some alcohol burn in the finish.  On the whole, not bad, but with too much sweetness and too much foreground alcohol.

25 oz bottle.  Pours a nice cola color with sufficiently thick white, full foam head.  Aroma is sweet booze, vanilla, yeast, and some dark fruit.  Very complex, subtle flavor; peaches, wheat, earth, well-disguised alcohol.  I am partial to unibroue, so this review cant be taken too seriously, but this is just a VERY nice evening time beer.  Best of the day, and Im glad I waited.  It has a relatively static palate,but when you start good, you dont have to move too much.  Yum.

Bottle opened with a load pop followed by tons of yummy beer smoke pouring out. Body is dark opaque brown with a massive tan crown floating on top, the retention is just stupid I had to wait ten min. for the head to slowly settle down so I could get a sip in. Aroma is wheat, yeast, perfume, summer fruit (peach maybe) and just a hint of the 10% alcohol. Very smooth flavor built on a wheat back bone, vanilla, yeast, plums, and tons of perfume all make into the taste. The alcohol starts to come out a bit too much when warmer but nothing too harsh. This yet another high quality brew from Unibroue doing what they do best.
Bottle, brown color. Coca cola, Dr. pepper aroma. Nice thick feel, brown sugar, dried fruit and cola taste.  Nice beer, me gusta.

Smells of fruit and hearth with massive oak and vanilla tones. Pours a very nice reddish brown with a great white creamy head. Another amazing carbonation and body from this brewery. Top notch. This is one of the most interesting and complex beers I have ever had. Huge Plum and rasins and vanilla. But what really stud out was the buttery complexity. I really thought I was drinking an highly oaked Merlot. This was stunning.

Pours medium brown with a white head os small bubbles.  Flavor is sweet with caramelized fruit in the foreground.  Mouthfeel is a bit sticky, but has a good amount of carbonation.  There is a fairly strong alcohol presence along with a bitter hop finish.  A good strong ale.

Pours a medium to dark brown with a large fluffy head. Aroma is spicy, yeasty, bready, dusty too. Not much sweetness in the aroma. Flavor is heavily boozy, with a lot of yeast, prunes and toffee/maple. Palate is creamy, with a burning alcohol finish. This is probably my least favorite from Unibroue so far, though still not bad. Overall, good.
Bottle, thanks to larsniclas. Brown color, nice beige head. Fruity aroma, vanilla, milk, peach and some spices. Malty flavor, fruity, yeasty, solvent. Solvent malty finish.

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark cloudy amber large frothy light tan head that lasts awhile leaving behind good stick lacing. The aroma is a spicy fruit malt with raisin and caramel. Thin mouthfeel with brown sugar and yeast with a spicy finish. Hides the alcohol well, a very good belgian strong ale from Unibroue.

bottle from metzlers in denton tx.  poured a murky brown with a nice beige head.  aroma of caramel, dark fruits, cinnamon, vanilla, and some orange zest.  flavor was spice, orange, dark fruits, and alcohol.  light-medium body with high carbonation.  a good one but not my favorite by them.

Sample at the Unibroue tasting at Blacklick Wine and Spirits on 4.10.09.  Deep amber pour with a big tan head.  Aroma of yeast, sugar and A1 steak sauce.  Malty flavor up front with yeast and some alcohol.  A bit coffee and hops in the finish.  Didnt get the A1 in the flavor.

An interesting beer. Nice medium head on a cloudy amber color. Seems to have an almost clove like flavor. Certainly lots of spices but cloves or perhaps even nutmeg the strongest. Lots of alcohol presence and heavy hops. good beer but too much of the clove flavor/

Bottle from Specs. Lovely in the glass, dark muddy mahogany with very fine silt-like sediment that swirls in iridescent ribbons. Tan creamy head with nice retention. Buttery aroma with  sweet sugary malt, flavor is creamy sugar with caramel and dark fruits. Ethanol can be felt but not unpleasant. Very nice. One of my favorites.

Bottle. Pours dark red with white head. Aroma is dark fruits, spices and belgian yeast. Flavor is spicy with notes of toffee, caramel, and dark fruits. Finish is a little hot, perhaps more aging will take the edge off.

Not to take anything away from it, but Im not a huge fan.  Its aroma is full of dark fruits, spice, and certainly lots of alcohol.  The appearance is a gorgeous fluff-white head on a very dark ruby body.  Exceptional lacing.  The flavor is full, a bit much.  The dark fruits, spices, and alcohol become a bit to strong for me.  The balance of this with the alcohol burns, makes for a really, really slow drink.  A one and done for me.  Although it left me feeling quite knackered.
Bottle shared with Steve and Eric.  Interesting beer.  Somewhat sour aroma and flavor.  Tastes of year old lemons and apricots (in a good way).  Finishes nicely with the Belgian funk.

I tasted that one over a year ago, the first time I saw it, and I have been quite disappointed.  Too fizzy, not very balanced, more displeasingly sour than sweet or bitter.  But a year has passed, the economy has been ruined, but this beer developped interesting spicy and alchool aroma and layers of complex flavors pretty hard to describe (notes of brown sugar, dates, many spices, orange, typical Unibroue yeast) but the bitterness comes much after, quite strongly.  But how will it age?  This is a hell of a mystery beer to me.  I like that, but it is very spicy which I like less.

Bottled from Systembolaget. Vintage app. 2006.
Dark brown with a huge, tan head.
Yeasty and sourish aroma; coriander and chlorine.
Soft and smooth palate.
Fruity and yeasty with tangerine and apricots.

pours with a stable cream head .. . musty cherry, tobacco, jam, alcohol and basement flavours, also similar in the nose .. . slightly sour slightly sweet, nice link up .. . good but seems less than last 2 years .. abv is fairly well hidden too .. . wwf: pandas that wrestle ... ..
Oooh la la. This is one of the best Unibroues i have ever had. Its so smooth, so full of flavor. As always, lots of rich malts. Pours dark, lots of head that slowly goes down. Great.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2009 hazed cocoa maroon body with a hell of a head. on it. love the nose on this thingherbal sweet fruits and a vanilla scent. damn this tastes even better. everything the nose [romised and more. great full mouth feel, i dont know if it is because im so fng stoned or if the beer is this fing good?the light banana yeast notes are rich and just end this beer amazingly well. plum deep caramel almost chocol;ate notes. just a bit of peach sweetness and lingering sugariness. this is a joy to drink. of course the red chili soy ginger chicken and rice i just had with this may have played a part too.
3 10 10  5 20

rerate:
yes i was that stoned, and yes the beer was that good.

If it wasnt so sugary, Id love it: cloudy, dark brown body with average head and lacing; sweet and lightly spiced aroma and flavor with a great blend among bitter, salt, and sour; good, but could do without the obvious sugariness.

750 ml bottle...pours cloudy cola brown with a  thick tan head. Aromas of dark fruits (raisins, and black cherries), candied sugar, vanilla, caramel, and some slightly funky yeast. The flavor was sweet without being obtrusive, with the vanilla and dark fruits prevailing. The palate was moderately carbonated, medium bodied, and finished hot with alcohol. A very complex sipper...
In the bottle at the 2009 Crescent Moon Extreme Beerfest. Pours a cloudy brown with a thick creamy head. Nice wheat and lemon flavors. Strong ethanol. Lots of cherries and oakiness as well.

Great Unibroue beer.  Typical sort of mouthfeel, which you come to expect when drinking Unibroue products.  Maybe the most attractive of their beers in terms of coloration - a nice deep ruby color.  Lacks a strong aroma, which seems strange to me.  Flavor is largely sweet fruits, though the aftertaste balances it a bit by being slightly more bitter.  Alcohol is noticeable, and not as well integrated as I would have expected.
PPWD Trade Show. Great beer. Nice dark color and flavor. Dark fruits, and yet hints of chocolate malts. Somewhat strong but not to the point of being undrinkable. Great effort.

750ml bottle at Novare Res.
Pours a dark cloudy reddish color.  The aroma is dark fruits like cherrys and plums.  Flavor is nice alcohol, prunes, sweet and almost wine like.  This is a nice beer, i was really impressed.

750ml bottle. Pours dark red with nice foamy white head. Aroma of red fruits, touch of alcohol. Nice aroma but not very complex. Very sweet taste. ripe fruits and prunes and blackcurrant. Almost too sweet depending on what you are into at the moment. Rating #41
very nice brown tan head with a nice aroma of chocolate and spices. thought the 16 was better very strong alc.

0.75 l bottle. Brown colour with a tan, creamy head. Very interesting aroma with chocolate, spices, bonbon, orange zest and Speyside malt. Vanilla oaks rule as well. Good orangey chocolate flavours with yeasty notes and very nice vanilla oakiness. Spicy finish. A 17 year-old to be taken very seriously.

I acquired a delicious bottle of this beer in Quebec City. It pours a dark malty color with a good, thick head. It has a nice malty flavor with subtle sweetness, and a bit of booziness at the end coming in at a whopping 10 percent. I am glad I was able to try this about a week after the 16.
Pours dark amber brown, dark fruits, caramel, spices, brown sugar, little yeasty, little alcohol.

Pours dark and cloudy...medium head. Bitter and sweet together. Flavors of orange zest and dried fruit, maybe prune. Aftertaste coffee and chocolate. A bit of a cognac-like mouthfeel. Definitive alcohol burn. Probably my favorite Unibroue product sampled thus far.

Picked up at a BevMo in San Fran in a 750. Dark reddish brown pour with a solid creamy white head. Nice fruit esters in the aroma, cherry and plum being most notable. Also nice flavor of those fruits plus brown sugar and some light spiciness. Smooth finish to an overall solid brew.

Found this at Willowbrook binnys. Brown pour with big ol white head. Malty aroma with some oak, spice and vanilla. Some fruit. Flavor is fruity. Some vanilla, mostly dark fruit and spices. Warming alcohol presence. Great beer.
I am not actually leaving a comment, this is me opting out of that. However there are a minimum number of characters i must type so... You should all worship heavy metal!
dark red to brown, creamy head. nice sweet, malt taste with a long and complex finish.
Brown in color and hazy with a thick off-white head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with some caramel and a yeasty character. Taste is of fruit and sweet malts.

Dark brown body with ruby tinges and a light tan head. Some cherry on the nose but notice it more in the taste, brown sugar making it a touch heavy, other spices and dried fruit. Drinks alright but didnt really turn me on.

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a cloudy copper brown with a lasting amber head and good lacing. Aromas of cherry, plum, carmel, brown sugar and spice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a lightly warming finish. Flavors of cherry, plum, carmel, brown sugar and light spice with a smooth lightly warming lightly sweet finish.
bottle, dark brown pour with strong tight foam, aroma of spicy fruit, flavors very belgian caramel and cloves, finish lingers

Bottle. Clean brown with lacing and a thick film of bubbles. Nose-banana, clove, Belgian yeast. Taste-candies banana, brown sugar, cigarette smoke aftertaste, alcohol burn, grape, sticky raisin. The yeast strain is very very Belgian. Overly sweet, brown sugar, fig, sweet dark fruit. Yeast really takes center stage with the candied banana. Decent, but a little too sweet.

Brown pour with red highlights and a foamy white head.  Aroma contained brown sugar and cherries.  The flavor was rich dark cherries and other fruit, some toasty brown sugar and a hint of chocolate.  Another good offering from Unibroue.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2009 Acheté au métro leblanc en format de 750 ml millésimé et embouteillé le 4 décembre 2007 et dégusté dans un verre de westmalle. Apparence brune foncé avec de léger dépôt et une mousse tenace et persistante. Cette bière offre des arômes délicats et explosif de complexité olfactives. Une touche de fruits mûres, dépices multiples comme le poivre et la muscade. Il y a aussi une touche de caramel et de levures arômatiques accentué dun touche de vanille bourbon. Merveilleux cette complexité gustative, une seul gorgée et déjà mes papilles en redemendent. Du clou de giroffe, du malt, du crémeux, des raisins sec, de lalcool, du gingembre, des prunes et une sensation de vieillissement en fût de chêne. Il y a aussi un léger goût de canneberge séché et de canelle suivis dune touche de réglisse. Déjà un an et cette bière dévoilent un long potentiel daffinage en cave. Une pure merveille et je vous la suggère entre 12 et 14 degré celcius. À consommer lentement par petite gorgée, juste wow!

Reviewed 1/20/2009 (bottle dated December 2010):

Pours a very dark brown reddish colored body with a foamy, off-white head, average size and lasting. Very fruity, dark fruit aroma.  Some hops, and alcohol. Berries, and maybe some sweet honey too. Very flowery aroma. Flowery taste, somewhat fizzy, somewhat creamy palate.  Dark fruit.  Pretty clean aftertaste. Fig and some alcohol. Very floral on the breath, and the aftertaste. Some sweet spiciness in the taste too.  Almost sickly sweet.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 A delicious spicy beer only offset by the smell of oysters and not very inspiring brown color. Spices are very strong, coriander, thyme, none of the sweet stuff. I could imagine drinking this with a shrimp cocktail. $10 at Crown. Im sorry, but I just couldnt finish it. Not my cup of tea, or more likely, not my cup of fish oil.

Thick dark brown pour, big foamy white head. Dark fruit, very sweet aroma, caramelized sugar, some yeast, some smoke and wood as well - not typical Unibroue. Taste - was this oak aged? I did not read the label. Heavy vanilla oak taste, blends so well with the yeasty, dark fruit and alcohol. Lots of smoke and peat in finish

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2009 750mL Bottle. Pours a dark brown body with a lot of head. The aroma is sweet malt and something else I either cant describe or dont remember. The taste is great, like most Unibrews. A great balance of yeast, spice and alcohol. Awesome brew.

750ml bottle. Pours cloudy dark brown with a smallish off-white head. Aroma and flavor are both quite complex and nice. Mixtures of toffee, dark fruits, tart fruits, yeast, mild spices, etc. Lots of stuff going on, and all meshes and balances very nicely, leaving an oddly understated impression despite being quite flavorful. Recommended.

I have neglected to keep up with this series of anniversary beers mainly because I usually do not care for them when fresh. This one is not that much different.  It is a little hot and the sweetness takes over most everything else. Big yeast aroma with some grass and spice is nice. Flavor is not all that memorable or complex after a bit of fruit upfront and the sweetness on the finish.

750ml bottle poured into a tumbler.  U17 pours murky and walnut brown with a large fluffy head that has no intentions of going anywhere anytime soon.  The aroma is peppery with strong alcohol.  It also contains raisin and whiskey barrel oak smells.  This beer smells like a serious drink, not like a typical beer.  The taste includes vanilla, cream, black pepper and cola.  The higher-than-average carbonation pushes the beer through the mouth nicely and prevents the alcohol from lingering on the tongue.  This is a very nice beer that I feel should be sipped for full enjoyment.  Sip frequently though.  There is no sense in wasting 10 percent ABV!

Pour was a slightly turbid brown with some ruby highlights.  A short, almost fizzy off white head appeared and collapsed quickly.  The aroma was malt, yeast, pepper and sweeter spice.  The flavor was dominated by malt and yeast with light peppery spices, softer chocolate and cinnamon and some unchecked alcohol heat.  Average mouthfeel.  Seems like there might be something to this one that a year or two or three of cellaring might help.

Pours chestnut deep with beautiful head, lasting too.  Yeasty bready notes are first noticed but there are toasty malt and berry aromas.  Chewy syrupy body has dusty roasted fruit qualities, berry and green apple.  Therre is a vanilla oakiness present as well which adds a little bit of developing complexity as the bottle empties.  The lingering booziness makes its presence felt but does not overwhelm, this is a stronger one.  Nice level of carbonation allows for nice mouthfeel and drinkability.

Thin frothy head of offwhite bubbles in my chalice.  Reduces to a bevy of carbonation hotspots.  Rich roasty and malty aroma with some yeast, raisins, spices and caramel malts.  Very tempting.  Color is a hazy chocolate brown.  Dark malts and maple syrup.  Thick and chewey palate with a big alcohol kick.  Sweetness abounds with a bit of lingering late spice and yeast.  Quite the pleasure to drink.  Bit of a tarty lump remaining in my throat.  Finishes dry and pasty with lingering spices.  A slightly above average for Unibroue but still in their typical style.

Dark amber/brown in color with a very nice rocky, creamy tan head.  Body is hazy.  Aroma was terrific.  Mainly sweet malts, caramel, some sweet orange peels, and yeast.  I thought the flavor was a bit of a let down.  I was really excited after the appearance and aroma, but the flavor was overly alcoholic.  This brew was smooth going down, but the alcohol lingers a long time.  Overall, a little disappointing.

Dark brown with a medium tanish head. Lots of sediment noced in my glass.
Smells heavy on the rasins and dates with molasses and alcohol.Taste is sweet to start at first and ends with a heavy alcohol feel. Very full flavored and a bit bitter at the end.Good carbonation but a little bit of a bitter finish.A good beer but not the best Unibroue has of this style.

Bottle 75cl. at home.Clear medium amber color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light light heavy malty, caramel, perfume, fruity, pumpkin, moderate to light light heavy yeasty, spicy, wood, peppery, alcohol, ginger notes,. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a long duration, with a spicy ginger - peppery spike. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [150908]

Attractive reddish brown out of the caged cork bottle with a lasting biege foamy head.  Nicely carbonated.  Nose of noticable alcohol and dark fruits.  This is a big beer and the 10% gets more pronounced as it warms.  Lots of raisen, fig, and dark cherries with light molassess, oak, and spice.  Very easy sipping beer.

Reddish brown with a large foamy head. Aroma of fruit and spice. Flavor has the fruit and spice but also some vanilla bourbon notes along with an oak taste. Very nice finish. Very drinkable with no hint of alcohol until you stand up.
Brownish color. Lots of head. Alcohol noticeable in taste. Taste is mostly spice, with no sweet, sour or bitter.

Color is a deep solid brown with a hint of orange.  Carbonation is very good with a big tight off white head.  Aroma is a fruity Belgian yeast scent with a slight sour note.  Taste is fruity and twangy.  It starts with a medium body that goes down fizzy and foamy.  Finish comes in bright with a funky sour taste that is followed up with a spicy cinnamon and clove like taste.  After taste is a lingering of this spicy taste with a sweet alcohol feel.  Overall I don’t think this is one of Unibroues better showings, its just a bit too funky
Wow.  I can see why this is so highly rated.  Pours quite brown.  Nice and smooth on the palate.  Nicely fruited and spice. Way to go Unibroue.

crazy spice nose, maybe some wormwood.  salty and sour with slight warming.  deep ruby orange and sugar.  a spice explosion.  cinnamon and pears.  slight spruce.  interesting, but not a beer to drin a lot of.

I drank this one on election night in while celebrating the results. Screw champagne! I expected this one to be golden in color and was surprised by its browness. Lots of dark fruit. Somewhat syrupy. Plum, fig, raisin, maybe a touch of caramel, and a bit of molasses. Lively carbonation. Solid.
Shared by Ethan.  Didn’t care for this anniversary too much.  Heavy dark fruit and molasses flavor.  Unibroue house character nowhere to be found.  Odd.

750 mL bottle - pours a dense, medium brown head. Full body of flavors typically associated with these brews. Plenty of carbonation. Masked, but noticeable taste of higher alcohol content. The Unibroue guys produce some good stuff!

750 ml bottle.  Pours a rich dark mahogany with a dense tan head.  Nice full nose of fig, raisin, caramel and toffee.  Medium to heavy body.  Rich palette of figs, apricot and raisins in a velvety texture with a moderate bitterness and moderate alcohol warming.  Slightly tart, lingering finish.

Dark brown with a foamy light tan head that leaves foam on the top of the liquid for the duration.  Smells like rum, malt and fresh dark cherries.  Taste is slightly like soy sauce, with sugar and more more dark cherries.  Nice warming beer.
Bottled.  Hazy mahogany colour, rich firm head. Intense fruity roasted chestnut aroma. Sweet and fruity. caramelly and faiely lively with prunes and overripe plums. Feels dusty and mature.

Pours a murky brown with a two finger creamy light tan head. The nose is sweet, raisiny, malty, has a rummy character, light alcohol, some earthy/Belgian yeast character begins to appear with warmth as does a mild Abbey Dubbel character. The flavor was sweet, earthy, Belgian, malty, chocolate, alcohol, molasses, light rum. The palate was warm with a full round carbonation. This doesn’t seem to fall in line with most of their other stuff. Lacks a certain unibroue character, still good though.

hazy brown, with mild head.  sweet nose, flavor of dark candi sugar, crystal malt, probably some special B giving it the raison flavor, some good depth.  mild hop bitterness.  a good beer, not spectacular

Bomber, shared.  Pours a deep reddish brown with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma is candi sugar, spices, and dark fruit.  Flavor is heavy spice up front, dissolving into dark fruit, caramel, malt, candi sugar, and a detectable alcohol burn at the end.  The aftertaste is lingering, and the beer remains sublimely smooth throughout.  Its a great beer, but when youre talking about Unibroue, is that even news?

Milky copper-brown, creamy off-white head.
Sweet, spicy, raisiny nose.
Strong spicy flavor:  raisins and plums.
Major alcohol, caramel and some earthiness.
Slightly lingering, then fades.

Mahogany colored ale with a large, authentically Belgian head.  Fairly nice nose hints of dark fruit, spice cake, brown sugar and earth.  Flavor is very unique and complex, with lots of taste.  Notes of chocolate, cocoa and hazelnut along with a touch of dried cherry, red plum and espresso.  Impressive in every way.  Lots of flavor and aroma character.

Deep mahogany pour, ruby highlights and a huge rocky off-white head.  Classic Unibroue dusty and slightly funky yeast aroma with lots of dank bready malt, moderate dark fruits, some orange and coriander.  Flavor has lots of zesty citrus, with notes of plums, dates, pepper, alcohol, and a vinous finish.  Medium to full body with a potent dose of carbonation.  Great complexity.  One of Unibroue’s best offerings I’ve had in a while.

Pours dark caramel color with off white head. Aromas of bread dough and spices. Sweet, dark fruits and some spiciness with the Unibroue house yeast flavor. Medium body with lively carbonation and a slightly dry finish. A nice brew.

Each year Unibroue brews a new Anniversary beer to celebrate, well, their anniversary. This year around I am helping Unibroue to celebrate their 17th Anniversary. A Belgian strong ale in terms of style, while the ABV may be high, 17 is delicate, whimsical, and personally one of the best beers I have tasted lately and can enjoy on a regular basis.

Sharing my bottle with my girlfriend, my 17 poured once more with an indomitable head of foam which occupied more space than the actual liquid brew herself. I always pour my beers slowly, but I was still amazed at how quickly her head almost toppled over the rim of my glass. Never one to rush a good thing, I waited for the head to fade before slowly topping her off. Of course, each step down, the head left soft and puffy layers of brussels lace along the sides. A light khaki in color, she covers my 17 below which is a lightly see-through brown. Bubbles cling to the side and slowly rise to the surface. In her nose I detect caramel, nuts, and fresh rye bread. My first few quaffs reveal a crisp effervescence that is marked by a full mouthfeel and thick body. Toffee, licorice, and crisp red apples are finished by a light bitter hop presence of grapefruit. Her finish is only mildly dry, choosing to leave instead a soft, decadent reminder of her sweet, chewy, bready body marked by apple notes and spice. A tinge of spice comes into play as my brew warms and I near the end of my glass. Very clean, tasty, smooth and full with just the right bite to round her off.

My only regret is that because the Unibroue 17 is an anniversary beer, once she is gone then she is gone and I shan’t ever partake of her deliciousness ever again. Of course, in preparation of that inevitability, I plan on setting aside at least one bottle to savor at an unknown later date. I could rave forever about Unibroue’s 17th Anniversary Belgian Strong Ale, but I would rather the uninitiated taste it themselves and discover the wonder contained within a 750ml corked bottle.
Orange brown cloudy color. Yeasty and bready aroma. Biscuity flavor with some citrus and coriander. Some molasses and grape as well.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2009 This was superb. 750 mL bottle. Pours a  cloudy bright brown (almost golden) with a large, off-white head. Nose is very spicy with some cloves, orange peel, and cinnamon. Taste is fairly sweet with lots of brown sugar, cloves, yeast, and earthiness in the flavor. I agree that there could be some banana in there. The dark fruits and spice hide the alcohol well. Nicely balanced- very refined. Toss in the yeast sediment at the bottom and it muddles some of the complex flavors but still great.

Had the pleasure of trying this beer at a North Carolina Beer Festival. This is my favorite Belgian strong ale, thus far. Loads of dark fruits- a very rich flavor that lingers on your palate. Loved it.

Mmmmm, belgian strong ale. Another great BSA from Unibroue. This one tastes heavily of wood, though not much vanilla that usually comes with that woody goodness which was a lovely exclusion for me. Tons of dark fruits, and lots of cloves and banana tastes in this one, like a dark banana brew that is astringently alcoholic. Awesome.

0.75 l bottle. Hazy mahagony color with creamy peige head. Perfumed and spicy aroma with pepper, clove, coriander, cardamon, licorice, orange peel, cork and hints of chocolate. Very spicy flavor with pepper, clove, orange, licorice, tart fruitiness, chocolate and dry woody yeastiness. Highly carbonated, too gassy. This is also too spicy, maybe this needs aging. Overall this is fairly rich and  satisfying brew.

bottle with homer321: pours dusty brown colour with a big fluffy off white head. aroma is a sprucy earth aroam , sweet sugar malts, spicy cinnamon and fruits. flavour is great, lovely spruse spice with winter fruits and sugary malts. very good.

75 cl bottle, thanks ekstedt. Brown, cloudy, with a frothy, mostly lasting, off-white head leavin a fair amount of lacing. Burnt notes, but also grass, leather, damp cellar and tree. Moderately sweet with light bitterness. Medium bodied, somewhat oily with soft carbonation.
Bottle (75 cl) from Systembolaget. Murky brown with medium off-white head. Strange fruity aroma with notes of wood, coconut and vanilla. Well balanced with a dry finish.
Cloudy, dark brown colour. Light white head. Malty nose with a hint of spice to it. Pretty  heavy on the malt for the taste, with hints of spice, as expected.

Dirty Mississippi mud in color with a climbing tan foam head.  Aroma is dark fruit, cherry skin, brown sugar, toffee, and oak.  The flavors of vanilla, molasses, caramel, and spice have melded well and hide the 10% ABV remarkably well.  This is a very well put together, highly drinkable brew.  Grab one if you can!!!
Poured a dark tannish color with a small fluffy with head. Kinda foggy. Real sour tasting. Sweet maltiness. Dark fuits in the flavor.

Bottle... Murky caramel-colored ale with a large, frothy, khaki head. Excellent, small, creamy, mushroom cloud-like retention. Weeping lacework. The complex aroma can be described using all these words: vinous, woodsy, acidic, earthy, malty, herbal, spicy, Flemish, perfumey, praline and dark fruits. Throw all those against a wall and theyll stick. Medium to full-bodied with fizzy carbonation. Sweet; but sufficiently bitter and tart to maintain balance. Woodsy, funky and Flemish. Lengthy, moderately sweet finish.

Dark brown pour with a small tan head.  Wood flavor with yeast and coconut(?), wood, and vanilla. Nicely complex and some super spice flavors.  Did not expect coconut. Pleasant zest.  Almost with the best of its breed.

Courtesy of oh6gdx. It’s red-brown with a creamy head. The aroma is rather complex with notes of spice, oak, vanilla and pumpkin. The flavour has sweetness and notes of alcohol, vanilla, oak, spice, caramel, raisin and pumpkin. It’s complex, but needs maturing to develop the full potential.

pours heavy with lots of head.  dark amber color with a scent of fermented fruit and some caramel.  very smooth taste with tones of malt and fruit.  finish is smooth with a warming feeling as it goes down.  would purchase again.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2008 Aroma: sourish, yeast, coriander, citrus, cranberries, caramelt malt, darker malt, vanilla, coconut... Vinous, mint... armagnac... butter flavoured popcorns. 
Flavour: sweetish, powerful, mild rowanberry, malty, yeasty. This is great. Vaguely of saffron (semi-bitter). Roasted apple lingers throughout. Green grapes. A bit too mild & sweet to score higher. 
Palate: soft, fizzy as usual (with Unibroue) - though not overpowering. 
Appearance: slightly murky deep red copper body w/ frothy yellowish beige head leaving rustic lacing.
Bottle. Really sweet taste with lots of raisans and some caramel. Malty and sweet finish.

Chocolate brown, hazy/murky pour from 750ml bottle.  Huge, off white head taking its time to dissipate.  Aroma of caramel and some flower, sweet with a bitter finish.  A malty concoction with a Belgian influence.

Bottle shared by firmbuttstone. Poured a murky brown orange color with a light tan head. Lots of spices (esp clove), pastry, vanilla, and flowery hop in the aroma. There was also a whiff of rubber. Medium bodied and slightly sweet with mild bitterness and moderate to high carbonation. Citrus and tar graced the flavor and made for a nice combination there was also some flowery hops, light alcohol, and a dash of powdered sugar. Delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 Would pour, if you dont pour very slowly, a 5+ finger light tan thick whip cream head that fades very slowly leaving a good lace. Hazy amber color. Good carbonation and medium-heavy bodied. Sweet malty nose. Flavor is sweet plums, caramel and raisins.  Some yeastiness in finish. High ABV is hidden.  $8.60 for a 750ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

Grande Reserve 17 is different -
Pours a two-finger cream head that fades slowly leaving some lace.  Hazy brown color.  Light carbonation and medium bodied.  Dark fruit nose and flavor is semi-sweet dark fruit and oak. Some yeastiness in finish. High ABV is hidden. Good dark ale but Unibroues Trois Pistoles is better and cheaper. $11.99 for a caged and corked 750ml bottle from The Meat House Pembroke, NH.

Bottled: Pours dark reddish brown with a big, thick head. Aroma has yeast,  coriander, orange peels, nutmeg and black currants. Flavour is sweet and spicy and vinous. The finish is alcohol bitter and warming.

Very nice aroma, with thick complex, but subtle smell. The appearance is wonderful, beautiful colour, nice foam and a very beautiful bottle. The taste is complex, with many flavours but none as strong so it takes out another. Great beer!
A dark mahogany brew withh a beige head, this strong ale succeeds in balancing the sweet malt and chocolate notes with hops and smooth carbonation level.  Very much a winning strong brown ale.

750 ml bottle. Pours a dark mahogany hue with a large beige head. The aroma suggests all the nice aspects of Unibroue; lots of yeast and spices, plus a light malt and fruitiness. The flavor is very nice; initially dominated by loads of spices; clove and cinnamon mostly. There is a rich yeast aspect too, along with some dark fruits and sweet chocolates and other sweets. I drank the whole 750 during the Steelers victory, and it went down very easy. As usual, I enjoy this brewery’s well-crafted beer.

Bottle.

Head is initially large, frothy, light brown, fully lasting.
Body is hazy medium to dark brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted bread, caramel), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs), with light notes of cinnamon, bark, clove.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Surprisingly good. The aroma is a bit mild, but whats there is quite pleasant...spices very much in the cinnamon/clove/etc. vein, but not in a *spiced* way...subtle and mild, as if from the yeast rather than spice additions.  I had this side-by-side with the 2008 Lost Abbey Ten Commandments, and despite this not being an absolute blockbuster, it totally demolished the Lost Abbey.  Not even close.  A much better yeast strain, much better carbonation level, and much better flavor balance. Not quite a world-beater, but a delightful, solid, strong Belgian-styled brown ale that was remarkably difficult to keep from quaffing, as if it might be a 5% brown ale.  I doubt theyll ever match the beauty of the Unibroue 11, but this is a highly commendable effort.  Its difficult to win me over with strong Belgian browns, but this one has done it.

750ml bottle.  Interesting aroma, musty, vinous, fruity, darkly sweet, herbal and spicy, with notes of red grape, pomegranate, cinnamon apple, leather, old wood and faint citrus.  Deep, dark brown-red color, hazy, with a massively foamy, lasting head and lacing to match.  Flavor profile is bitter and citric to start, becoming mildly tart, winey and fruity, and finishing sweet and malty, with suggestions of cotton candy, raisin, orange, leafy herbs and peppery alcohol.  Effervescent, sharp, mildly warming and active on the palate, body is medium-full.  Lingering tea-like herbal touches.  Wow, what is this?   Not your typical Unibroue, for sure, other than the usual Belgian slant and the strength.

Bottled@Fonefan (thanks for the bottle omhper!). Amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is alcohol, raisins, toffee, soap and some mild spices. Flavour is hops, spices, some alcohol as well as mild birch sap. Probably needs a bit of aging, since it felt a bit strong, sharpedged and alcoholic.

Aroma is strong, rich, malty, with just a hint of fruit - probably apple - and a hoppy, "rubbery" undertone. Color is a warm clear mahogany, and it pours with a very thick beige head that hangs around for a bit. Flavor is rich and mouth-filling, smoky, nutty, with both sweet and bitter tones and hints of chocolate and molasses. Finish is smooth and leaves a hoppy aftertaste.

750 ml split in Westmalle glass.  Hazy brown with lasting tan head.  Spicy raisiny chocolate yeasty date-nut bready aroma.  Spicy fruity brown sugar maltiness with lotsa dark ripe fruit wheaty tang and complex spicy tangy finish.  Medium-full body and medium-low carbo makes for a nice full soft mouthfeel.  Well-conceived, tasty, complex and satisfying.  Well hidden alcohol.  Excellent.

Had this as part of a Unibroue tasting dinner.  Poured a deep brown.  Malty, barleywine-esque flavor.  Chocolate tones and a strong spiciness in the aroma.  Can sense the high alcohol content and oakiness in the aroma and taste.  An excellent ale, worth whatever you pay to get it.

(Bottle) Pours deep compact brown with glowing red lines. Big and stable off-white head. The aroma is of peppery spices, yeast and malt up front with tones of caramel, mild chocolate  roast, nuts, rye, brown sugar, white pepper, nutmeg, cinnamon, cardamom, sweet vanilla and ginger. Also rater fruity and soft vinous with tones of dark grapes, cherries, apples, pears, plums/prunes and hints of banana. Just a whisper of wood, oak, flowers, citrus peel and earth are also notable. The flavour is caramelly/chocolate malty, complex spicy (ginger, nutmeg, white pepper and cardamom), yeasty, fruity/citric, earthy and light acidic. Quite lingering sweet with a tiny dry finish. The sweetness is syrup and sticky with notes of liquid brown sugar and over ripe dark fruits. The mouthfeel and body is quite full, well carbonated and light creamy. The nose is fantastic, maybe just a bit out of focus from all the spiciness. The flavour is solid but not perfect; the sweetness is quite boring in the end. Is this beer oak aged or just blessed with a vanilla spiced wood-like note from somewhere else?

Cloudy brown color with a thin cream head.  Aroma is musty, spicy,  yeasty and has a slight hint of green apple sweetness.  Flavor has a real earthy aspect to it.  Not overly sweet or spicy like some Belgians, this one is pretty down to earth.  It is quite enjoyable, but not too memorable.

750ml bottle, barely chilled. A foamy brown pour coalesces into half chocolate-hued liquid and half energetic, sandy cauliflower foam. Stiff 3D lace sticks to glass and lips with equal fervor. The bouquet enchants with spicy-citric-fresh hay hops, frolicsome oaky Chardonnay and yeasty wine cellar, seductive caramel and Merlot, and piquant orange soda and cotton candy scents. Sipping reveals oaky/malty and nutmeg/allspice flavors… also qualities of pistachio and reedy chamomile. A nipping alcohol sting adds elvish complexity. The palate proves a study of creamy fullness sharpened by fizzy carbonation and crabapple tartness. A smooth woody/fruity finish glides effortlessly into a buttery lychee aftertaste that smarts with overripe orchard fruit and leatherclad bondage. I would love to taste this hopped to IPA or DIPA proportions. Distantly similar, but far superior to- Unibroue’s previous caramel apple and sweaty-tasting anniversary ales. Overall, an amazingly balanced, multidimensional, and truly unique beverage… a perfect coexistence of ale and young, aggressive white wine. Wow!
Bottle. Thick head, pine and cloves in the nose. Spicy Belgian-like flavour of yeast and burnt sugar, dark fruits and alcohol.

Bottle. Pours deep ruby brown with a creamy beige head. Fruity and yeast aroma with fresh banana, apple, and candy sugar. The flavor is a bit boozy and sweet, with fruit and yeast. Good, 16 is better right now, but given another year a bet this will improve a bit.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2009 20080919: First tasting Pours a darkbrown, almost red color (when holding it against light) with a nice head, leaving some lacing on the glass. Aroma of dried fruits, a bit yeasty and spicey, but also some unpleasant notes of leafs (almost rotten leaf). Not that pleasant and I wonder why I felt this way, since I have heard many good things about this beer. I shared it with a friend and he felt exactly the same. A bad  bottle, or did just some stupid imagination? Flavour is pretty sweet, quite vinous with a caramely maltiness but most of all dried fruits. It tastes better than the smell, but got some weak notes of these rotten leafs. Palate is a bit thin with quite much carbonation. This years biggest dissapointment. I have one bottle left, so lets hope the next one tastes good. 5/4/7/3/13=3,2

20090610: Second tasting. Pours a darkbrown color with a fantastic amber head. Aroma is really nice and vinous (mulled wine/redwine) with black and red currants, black currant leafs (not rotten, what was I thinking about last time?). Some caramel and sugar also. Flavour is quite sweet and malty but somehow the vinousity makes it balanced and I really love the black currant notes. Lightly yeasty. Very nice, smooth mouthfeel. Fullbodied and filling. Gôtt!

Apperance: Dark brown with a beige lace. Medium head.

Aroma: Caramel, Citric Notes, Spices, Fruit

Flavor: Chocolate, Toffee, Vanilla, Spices, Orange

Palate: Smooth with lots of carbonation and a decent bitterness balancing out the sweetness.

Best one from Unibroue in a while. I really liked this one and i’m glad a got a few more bottles stashed away. Recommended!

Bouteille de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, achetée chez La Barik (Trois-Rivières, QC). Arôme: Odeur de mélasse et de clou de Girofle. Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence d’un moyen col beige mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel foncé avec une pointe d’épices et de pommes. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #1963)

750ml bottle. Dark brown body below a lasting, big and frothy tan head. Inviting, complex aroma of fruit (plum, cherry, apple), fresh-cut wood from the whiskey-like alcohol, yeast (mustiness) and malts (rum-soaked cake and toffee).
