UPDATED: MAR 23, 2008 Bottle:  The aroma has lots of banana, dark fruits, brown sugar, yeast, and faint alcohol.  It pours a hazy reddish-brown with  very large beige head that has excellent retention.    Thick rings of lacing are left behind.  A rather impressive looking beer.  The flavor starts with lots of banana and light Unibroue yeastiness. The finish has an increased banana presence, brown sugar, dark fruit, nuts, apple, light alcohol, and a hint of smoke.  There is a very slight burn in the finish.  Medium bodied with moderate-heavy soft carbonation, which gives it a creamy mouth feel.  Obviously in the minority, but Im really digging this.  In my opinion, almost a Weizenbock-Quad combo.

Pours deep amber into a Tulip. Whiskey and alcohol aromas.  Off-white micro head recedes leaving spot lacing to skim surface.   Smooth bourbon from front to back with a lasting yeasty oaked bourbon finish.  Boozy.
Nice spicy brew from the aroma to the finish. Doesnt have too much lasting spice, but move of a thick creamy maltiness that I dont like too much. Overall, pretty good.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 from bevmo.  Dark mahogany brown with a foamy white head.  Amazing nutmeg, spice, and leather aroma.  Bright palate.  Chocolate, spice, cinnamon, wood, and tobacco taste.  A great complex beer.  One of the best from Unibroue.

750 ml. brown Belgian bottle. Corked and caged. Subdued pop releases the cork. Poured out a hazy dark brown color, with a sticky off white colored head. Aromas are of rum soaked prunes, brown sugar, lager yeast, Coca Cola. Flavors are of Coca Cola, prunes, raisins, yeast. Medium mouthfeel, burning alcohol in the throat.
Either this needs aging for about 5 years, or it needs reformulated at the brewery. Alcohol hits you like a ton of bricks in the end.
Hey, Unibroue, hows about making a decent tripel instead of all these damn dubbels & dark ales? I think youre trying to cover up a flaw in your brewing process with all these dark ales.

Taste from bottle at City Beer, San Francisco, 24th Feb 2008. Hazy mid brown with a lacy head. Very perfumy aroma and an interesting flavour of marshmallows, vanilla and spices. Great warming aftertaste. Very interesting stuff, Im keen to try this at length, but there is only so much beer you can fit in your luggage!

Pours a copper color with a tan head.  Aroma is of chocolate, slight roasted malt, spices, slight lemon, dark fruits, and some alcohol.  Light on the palate with the roasted malts and chocolate up front giving way to the lighter flavors of the lemon and dark fruits.  Finishes with the spices, alcohol warming, and some bitterness.

The pour reveals a murky brown color with amber highlights and a medium, bubbly, light brown head. In the nose, a chocolatey sweetness gets noticed first, then fruits appear, followed by a toasty, nutty malt and spices. The mouth is pretty much the same, sweetness, nutty, toasty malt, fruits and spices, some yeast. The body is light to medium with a liquorous texture and moderate carbonation. Not very impressive for a Unibroue but still pretty good.

big 750ml corked brown bottle

A: nice brownish-reddish amber colour with a lot of undense head that is mid-term long
S: fresh spicy nose,
T: very spicy mouth, long taste, good aftertaste, the yeasty taste in the last glass of the beer is very nice.

I like this beer

Bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, mabel, jerc & mds -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a murky dark orange-brown with a huge lasting foamy off-white head. Good lacing. Aromas a bit odd, but in a good way. Spicy & yeasty yes, but also hints of plastic (it works), oranges, alcohol and more -- wacky stuff. Flavours malty, yeasty and spicy along with some alcohol, dark fruit and a bitter, slightly harsh finish.  Medium to full bodied, creamy mouthfeel. This is quite good now and in a few years I predict it will be awesome.

Objectively speaking:
A new brown Unibroue anniversary beer that plays a concerto of strong cereal nuances atop the usual yeastiness, but surprisingly limited in fruitiness. Not vinous, but still liquorous.


I like:
The usual authentic unibroue palate with lively, yet uniform carbonation. Relatively drinkable. Interesting cerealic (straight barley, wheat, vanilla touched oatmeal) leaning, though a bit unidirectional for now. Quite toasty.



I dislike:
Belgianesque beige head departs quicker than is usual for a Unibroue. Frankly not much complexity for a beer of this magnitude. Lacking in fruit notes. Very sweet cereal syrup feel.

Deep hazed brown, light tan foamy head.  Cotton candy and spicy clove aromas with soft underlying notes of banana and dark fruit.  Spicy dark fruit and vanilla caramel flavors balance on just a touch rounding hop bitterness.  Full bodied, lively carbonation, spicy, fruity finish.  Its nice now, but some age could probably pull it together even more.

Sample at PCBF 08.  Pours a lightly hazy brown with a medium creamy off white head.  Aroma of sweet malts, some banana, Belgian yeast esters, nuts, caramel and some vanilla. Flavor of toasted sweet malts, nuts, vanilla, fruity and candy sugar.

(750ml bottle, thanks scraff) Large beige head atop cloudy brown body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, cotton candy, house yeast, banana, caramel, some nut.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, house yeast, some banana, white pepper, light alcohol burn.  Smooth medium-full body.  Seemed somewhat weizenbocky.

Mildly murky dark brown colored body with a tan head.  Nose of spicy brown sugar, quad-like yeast, spiced nutmeg bananas, some toast and some nuts.  Flavor is rich, sharp, boozy, and heavily influenced by the Belgian quad-like yeast being used.  Tastes of big boozy figs, nuts, dates, etc, with some sharp toasted banana as well.  A little too hot and too young, but overall quite good.

Bottle from Belmont Party. Poured clear dark brown color with medium frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Complex tart citrus, fruity and rye. Medium to heavy bittersweet spicy flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. Medium to full body with a sticky texture and small alcohol bite. Good brew.

750mL bottle, courtesy of scraff.  Thanks, Scott!  Pours a murky, dark brown color; very light tan head with solid retention and medium-bubbled lacing; excellent pour.  Lots of dry white pepper, spice, and brown sugar in the aroma; a solid, creamy, vanilla-tinged yeasty character.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy, creamy breadiness and toasty malts and a complex yeasty core; dried fruits, white pepper, and light spices; a solid, slightly boozy Belgian strong.  Lengthy finish, showing dried cloves, yeast, and white pepper; dry.

Courtesy of scraff. Hazy brown with a very large beige head, lasting, some lace. The nose is dark fruit, cotton candy, clove, apricot and banana. The flavor is moderately sweet with pepper, banana, pear, apple, herbs and lots of cotton candy. Medium/full body is soft and sticky with moderate carbonation.

2008-02-26. Bottle. Very dark brown body with a good sized beige head, and nice lacing. Odd spicey notes in the aroma, light hint of plastic or phenols that eventually blows off, alcohol, orange zest makes an appearance if you breath deep. (7+) Spice in the flavour lingers into the aftertaste, light fruit notes, sweet underlying malt. (7+) Average palate is a bit lighter than I would like personally. Pretty decent, bit of a puzzler but I enjoyed it. Bottle shared by HogTownHarry

Aroma:Spicy aroma,light fruity....
Appearance:light ruby-red,good tan lacing white head....
Flavor:furity-candy sugar,spicy,alcool...

Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, mabel, mds and jerc - my bottle.  Almost murky brick-red pour, thick fluffy tan rocky head.  Aroma - roast malt, tons of pungent spice, sweet, but also hints of plastic and iodine, dry citrus zest bitterness.   The taste - still sweet and spicy, plenty of dry pungent bitterness, herbal and boozy as it warms - the plastic emerges as overly pungent yeast/spice.  Thick, astringent, alcoholic body and finish - I liked it - its really raw, though.

Pours brown with amber highlights and tan head.  Spicy aroma- clove, cardamon, yeast, lemon, candied sugar, banana, dark fruit, pineapple.  Flavors of yeast, banana, orange, lemon, spice, slight hoppiness in the finish, and candied sugar.  Trademark Unibroue finish- extremely lively.  Really delicious.

The pour is brown, with a fluffy tan head. I very much agree with the Unibroue nose already mentioned... Its almost a signature smell.  Out of the anniversary ales Ive had from them, 10, 11, 2004, 2005, 15, 16, and now 17, I have to say this is one of the weakest. Not by much, but I just cant seem to rate it enough to top any of the others (though it is very close). I taste raisin, lots of clover and spice, alcohol, and some citrus. Ill cellar one and try it again with next years offering.

Pour is a cloudy Mississippi mud pour.  Aroma is all things Unibroue, very yeasty and dark fruit with a huge helping of candi sugar.  I could probably smell this and know it was a Unibroue w/o seeing the label.   Flavor is super dark fruit with a ton of spice and corriander.  Leaves a bready coating on the tounge as this goes down.  A very tasty style but this brewer doesn t really make a bad brew.

Tasted 2/19/2008.  750ml bottle.  Loud pop upon opening.  Thats fresh!  Ruby amber brown hue.  Spotty beige head.  Musty banana yeasty aromas.  Clove and spicy.  Raisins berries and cookie dough.  Good nose.  Full bodied and lively with tight effervescent and citrus acidity.  Perfumy Unibroue yeast character.  Cocoa and toffee.  Tart fruit and citrus fruits.  Good peppery hops in  the finish.  Lingering sweet   coating finish.  Could use some time to smooth the palate, but still very nice.

Bottle (750 ml, corked & caged) from Super Marche Rahman, Montreal. Pours a dark and slightly hazy ruby-amber with a crazy active body and a large, thick off-white head that leaves some remarkable lacing. Aroma is big and malty, with great fruit and spice notes, that trademark Unibroue yeast, and hints of tropical fruit juice and chocolate-covered raisins - very nice! Mouthfeel is full and spritzy. Flavour is a small step down from the aroma, but still very good - nice and malty off the top, with notes of chocolate and orange, some pineapple juice, dark fruit and yeast, and a surprising hit of hops in the finish. Couldve used a few months of aging to mellow a bit, but otherwise, this may well be the best Unibroue anniversary beer since 11.

Had I not known this was a unibroue I think I might have realized after the first few sips.  All of the unibroue beers seems to have some very fruity flavors going on and this was no exception.
Very pretty red-brown pour with a big brownish head.  Very good beer.

Happy Valentines Day to me.  Caged and corked, this pours an expansive cauldron of tight foam, only slowly surrendering a dark russet brew beneath.  The aroma has quite a phenolic aspect, with a stark spicy edge.  In a weird twist on the expected, my first impression of this is of tropical fruit punch, robustly sweet yet thick, meaty and pulpy.  What an interesting contrast.  I could see this going well with a pungent salad, some light game, or even with a hot fruit cobler.  (#3323, 2/14/2008)

Unibroues 10 and 11 might very well be the best belgian strong ale ever brewed in Québec. When Mr.Sleeman took over I tough that the seasonal strong ale tradition would not be followed by the new owner. Then Sapporo both Sleeman, I was even more worried about those great brews being cancelled due to market laws. I was wrong. #16 and #17 arent 10 and 11, but they still give you that little spicy unibroue yeast/alcohol hit that we all love. I was surprise by the #17, with a slight hop flavor and the very well hidden 10% alcohol. Very "Abbayes des Rocs" if you know what I mean...

Bottle - corked and caged 750mL. Dark ruby brown opaque pour with a voluminous tan head. Not unlike nearly every Unibroue pour. Nose is big yeast, spices, almost a leather conditioner type aroma, hops, flowers and dark fruits. Taste is spicy and hoppy with some almost licorice type flavors, dark fruits,  yeast and old flowers. Body is bubbly and medium overall. Very gaseous. Ends with more dark fruits, a plethora of spice flavors, dark bread, hops and Belgian yeast. Surprisingly different. I expected and typical dark Belgian ale that Unibroue typically produces. This has enough of a difference to be recognized.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2012 750 ml Grande Réserve version, purchased at Peluso (Montreal) on February 12, 2012. Dark brown, good head. Sweet aroma of spices, herbs and chocolate oak. Taste of sour berries and herbs, but it has a touch sweet, slightly woody and alcohol is subtle. Its really better than the first version!

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2008 Cloudy/muddy dark brown poor with a very tanned head, sticky.  Aromas are very yeasty (unibroue typical), very hoppy, dark fruits, prunes, raisins, dates and coriander.  Huge creamy body, sweet and a zesty hoppy mouthfeel.  Flavors of alcohol, orange zest, dark fruits, grapefruit and a spicy finish. Missing a little "je ne sais quoi" for an anniversary brew, will let this one sit for a while, still tastes very fresh.

C&C 750, best by December 2010. Very dark brown with a massive tan head that descends rockily. Very Unibroue nose - yeasty, dry, coriander and allspice, mildly fruity. Dry fruity flavors, some spicy orange and coriander, yeasty. A bit rough around the edges, clearly green.
